zM_mbhF09tlkTWatQxFfNg.text: Stuff is a bit pricey but high quality, fresh ingredients. Terrific place for a lunch. Seems to always be very busy.

mIPRce85qZOBTPmjotqTIw.text: So good!  What was supposed to be a 20-25 minute wait for a table turned into 10 minutes on a Sunday evening.  Great service, very friendly, explained anything we asked about.  The food was excellent!  We had the pork soup dumplings, vegetable dumplings, dan dan noodles, pork belly slider, marinated cucumbers, rolled onion pancake with sliced beef (ONE OF THE BEST THINGS I'VE EVER HAD ANYWHERE) and sweet egg yolk steamed bun.  I can't wait to go back and I wish they would open a location in the South Hills.

1l9D1i4f4XPx3rFYTA5hdg.text: Love this place! Super cool atmosphere. Watching the noodles being hand stretched is always fun. My favorites here are for sure the soup dumplings, pot stickers, and the spicy noodles! And of course a black bubble tea!

jkPc0HfmLgLNijehIHsB2g.text: I came here on my own the other day and was seated very quickly on one of the benches that are perfect for dining on your own or if you prefer not to wait and have 1-2 people with you.    I decided to go with the shrimp and pork wonton soup - which is actually soup as opposed to the other "soup" options which specify "steamed".  And also ordered the hot spicy wonton noodles under the "dry noodles" section of the menu.    On retrospect I should have ordered one or the other because it was wonton overload and generally food overload, I barely made a dent in either and had plenty to take home.  That being said, I enjoyed the soup and was able to eat about 2 of the wontons.  I was imagining a small bowl of soup but this could dish feed a family of 4 or more!  I wasn't in to the hot wonton noodle dish.  I got the wide flat noodles (as opposed to the thin rice noodles) so not sure if that made a huge difference because it was the flavor that didn't make me swoon.  You can definitely physically feel the heat of the dish but I didn't think there was much flavor.  I was sweating and my mouth was reacting to the spice but it was spicy hot as opposed to spicy flavorful.  Perhaps the name of the dish makes sense then.  I would be curious to go back and try something else.

VlYf1cWGIjo_kPmmxEpi4Q.text: Review by a vegetarian family with two young kids.   Several reviews have lamented the small number of vegetarian options on the menu and, while it is True that there are far more options for meat eaters and there is unfortunately no vegetarian noodle soup option, once you get over these 2 facts this is an excellent place for vegetarians.

CcrqxL7Ehc3tntC_sYCPAA.text: Okay PGH, this place is legit!  A place where you can get 'la mien' and actually watch them make it?  I hope people in this city realize how privileged they are to have a place exhibiting such craft.  Came here with my colleagues on a Saturday night, after hearing about this place several weeks ago.  Food (9.0/10) = Ordered the following dishes:  1) Braised beef and tendon noodle soup ($11) = A bowl of harmony created by the right quantity and proportions of fresh noodles, meat, vegetables, and stock.  Noodles were damn good. Beef cooked nicely.  Texture and softness of the tendons done perfectly.  2) Marinated sliced beef shank ($8) = great cold appetizer of thinly sliced beef.  3) Pork and crab meat soup dumplings ($8) = I'm impressed! honestly, was not expecting much since I've had it from it's origin of Shanghai.  8 little dumplings with pork/crab meat, without the overwhelming quantity of soup inside.  A lot of places I've been in the US have thicker dumpling dough.  This restaurant's dumplings have thinner wrapping, which I prefer. 4) Taiwanese pork belly slider ($6) = not sure what made this Taiwanese, but what I am sure about is, this pork belly bun is DD - damn delicious.  Pork belly is soft, and cooked long enough so that the fat no longer had the off-putting chewy fat texture.  There is a lot of flavor in the meat.  There is coriander and a crunchy texture as well (ground peanuts?).  What really made this dish stand out was it's size.  I have never seen a pork belly bun this big.  It's slightly larger than the area of my fist (see picture).  I'm impressed. 5) Taro milk tea ($4.50 + $0.50 per additional topping) = this was pretty standard in flavor.  There are other flavors offered. You can add toppings like red beans, mung beans, lychee jelly, and grass jelly as well.  Service (8.0/10) = service was fast and not overwhelming.  Our waiter was nice.  One thing I noticed and thought was nice is how they asked customers if they have had the soup dumplings before.  Reason?  It can be tricky to properly eat these little treats.  Without care, you risk busting the dumplings and wasting all the soup inside.  Eat too early, and you can potentially burn your tongue, screwing up the rest of your dinner and your tongue's ability to send 'flavor' to your brain the next 24 hours.  Ambiance (8.5/10) = I give this a higher score than I usually do, for the ability to watch them make their noodles.  Have you ever tried doing this?  It's hard, and this is why I'm more impressed with finding this place in PGH.    Overall opinion = as I mentioned, this city is privileged to have a restaurant like this.  I only expected to see such places in California, NYC, Boston, or Philadelphia (i.e places with an incredibly high concentration of Chinese).  So why not slap 5 yelp stars on this review?  Well, I've only been here once, and would like to sample other items on their menu.  Second, the prices are slightly higher than what I'm used to paying in cities such as NYC or Philly (pork/crab soup dumplings ~$7-8, la mien noodles $6-8, milk tea ~$3).  Despite the pricing, I'm still going to visit this restaurant again for sure.

9Lc0nE36quqriVZE-2cv9w.text: I first tried Everyday Noodles when they first opened and felt they were just blandly "Every day", but having gone back recently, they have mastered their craft!  Expertly prepared noodles, and the best soup dumplings I've had since Hong Kong.  Expect friendly service, an attractively remodeled modern asian atmosphere, and light, home made, flavorful, authentic, freshly prepared food.    Given all that, why isn't it a 5 that I want to go to "Every day"?  It has fairly limited menu options, and a few of the dishes are a bit timid.  Still all in all, a worthy contender against Squirrel Hill's many excellent asian eateries.  I can't get enough of their soups, noodles, and soup dumplings and I look forward to returning back again in the near future!

xVQdeS62MZiM6LktNtlnVw.text: Spectacular food and attentive service.  The potstickers were my favorite selection.  Just a heads up, the thai iced tea contains boba.  A welcome addition for me at least.

ywrBYyJVEYrhK94SHe8APw.text: Soup dumplings, just wonderful.  Had good experience there Thursday evening.  Had pan fried green onion pancake,  hot spicy wonton noodles, drunken chicken, pork vegetable potstickers.  Can't wait to go again!  Service was great, the waiter was helpful, attentive and polite.

jnrMkOUTlI4jGEw0kiHMfw.text: Liked it. Didn't love it. I went with a non-pork / non-spicy eater. There was one thing on the menu. Myself and the third person in the group enjoyed our food, but didn't love it. I'm not sure why this place is marked vegetarian as they told us they use pork brother for almost everything.

AitBO57c4h3UcYWshVpdNA.text: Authentic Taiwanese food in Pittsburgh!! Ordered a sampling of each category on the menu..( but two of the pork soup dumplings) and everything was relish. The soup dumplings were perfect. Thin dough covering a highly seasoned " meatball" of Asian goodness. The spicy wontons were not over the top spicy but just the right amount of heat+ flavor. Noodles perfect texture with sauces that weren't that heavy sweet stuff you get at Chinese restaurants. Im from Nj so Ive eaten Taiwanese in NYC.. And id say this place  can compete.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Noodles..dumplings..and more!!
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Spicy wontons

EJx916ZOe2U0I7667vbS4w.text: Hands down the best Chinese/Taiwanese in Pittsburgh. The food reviewer for the Post-Gazette gave this place a 2 star review when it first opened and was promptly castigated by members of the city's Taiwanese community, so that should tell you something. And my parents' house is nearby so I can get delivery when I'm home!  The xiao long bao are fantastic. I've never eaten them in a larger city like NYC so I can't compare, but these are juicy with a skin that's just thick enough to hold in all the soup and pork. I like the dan dan noodles, which are peanutty and vinegary, and the minced pork noodles and spicy wonton noodles as well. Oh, and the scallion pancake. Get the scallion pancake. You won't be disappointed.  Everyday Noodles can get extremely crowded at lunchtime, especially on weekends when it's populated by students from Oakland. But it's well worth the wait, and it's fun to watch the chefs behind the glass wall wrap xiao long bao and pull noodles at the counter.

tTb83QElznC8EB5r99pHVg.text: First off, I'm the type of person who panics when confronted with an unfamiliar menu. Suffice to say that my first glance at the Everyday Noodles menu was anxiety inducing.   Somehow, on this of all days, I had a breakthrough and instead of stumbling through my options trying to find the one perfect thing, my wife and I just started ordering stuff. Anything that caught our eye. And it worked.   We picked somewhat at random, partially based on descriptions, across different sections and ended up with a satisfying array of options. Plates and bowls of the Taiwanese style Dan Tsu Noodles, Vegetable Dumplings, Pork Wontons, Chicken Soup, and Steamed Broccoli were the end result.  The highlights of the day were the Pork Wontons with Mung Bean Noodles and the broth of the Dan Tsu Noodles. I wasn't a huge fan of the Vegetable Dumplings, but I think that was just my personal taste, as my wife did enjoy them.  The chicken in the soup wasn't super appetizing, but that may have been our only collective compliant. On the whole, it was a delicious and satisfying experience. There's not much that can beat a warm bowl of noodles on a cold winter day.   We will surely be back to explore more of the menu.

YT7g4RM1vXrP85TGBx2bYw.text: I was apprehensive about trying Everyday Noodles because the menu did not look vegetarian friendly and sometimes "vegetarian" still means it can contain fish sauce or shrimp paste/powder, plus I don't eat egg and figured the noodles were out....  So we called ahead and they told us there were vegetarian options without egg and without fish sauce etc. Looking at the menu, there are very few, almost none, of such options, just one noodle dish labelled vegetarian (cold sesame noodles) - and it was with egg noodles (the server kindly asked the kitchen for me). I was struggling. We were assured that the vegetable dumplings were vegan, so we started with those while further considering entree options. Just when I decided to simply get the dumplings and run, our super helpful server informed us that the Dan Dan noodle dish could be made vegan, less seafood products, and with rice noodles! So we stuck around.   The dumplings were absolutely adorable. And delicious! I'm pretty sure they are the best dumplings I've ever had. The filling consisted of shiitake mushrooms, some hearty green (kale?) and lil bits of tofu; very fresh and tasty.   We both also very much enjoyed the Dan Dan noodles (I got mine vegan, my partner got them "normal"). I thought the flavors of the dish were masterfully balanced, though I might ask for extra spicy next time. What was lacking in the dish was vegetables! Add some veggies to the dish, and I'd be giving a 5 star review.   My most pressing complaint is about the music. With fantastic food, excellent service and a pleasant enough space, they should re-consider their music selections because nobody should ever have to endure the likes of Reba McEntire and Celine Dion while enjoying soothing delights of the east. I'll take the generic Chinese music that you hear in every other Chinese restaurant over the worst songs of the 90s any day, though maybe not everyday.

Cz3PuseN_8nQVRbOf9CFqA.text: Everyday Noodles lives up to its name. If I could afford it, I would be there every night. Along with a noodle dish (I prefer the wide noodles) I particularly love the steamed Chinese watercress with the oyster sauce (vegetarian). But really, you can't go wrong. Everything is perfectly seasoned, no one dish out powers the others. I leave feeling completely satisfied.   Also, best bubble tea I've had in Pittsburgh, hands-down.

VJkml9JxEo8I1tbiE8B4Ig.text: This place is amazing. It's easily my favorite noodle restaurant to date. Get the pork soup dumplings for sure! Also, I met the owner last time I went and he was a super cool guy. Great to know we have cool business owners like this in Pittsburgh!

f97DOWSXNN2xHtwAXDQSLg.text: Great atmosphere and great food. This place must be the real deal considering (what seemed like) the entire Taiwanese population of Pittsburgh was eating there.   We had the spicy wonton and pork soup dumpling. Both were incredibly good. Can't wait to go back and try other dishes.

qQeLcci7KQQtf_0d2klrxQ.text: Went here for lunch on Sunday.  We shared a bunch of dishes to try and get a good idea of their menu and had quite a few leftovers.   The pork soup dumplings were very good.  They were delicious and just brothy enough to be savory, but not enough to be too hot to eat or to make a mess of my shirt.   Next we tried the pork belly bun.  This was not to my liking.  My husband was a fan, but only towards the bottom of the bun where the sauce was.  Before that it was dry and pretty flavorless.  The dan dan noodles had much more sauce and liquid than I expected especially since it is listed under dry noodles.  It was alright, but not great.   The pork belly over rice greatly eclipsed the noddles.  The rice was savory and delicious from the pork belly and the addition of the pickled mustard greens.  The pork belly was nicely stewed and a nice unctuous counterpart to the rice.  I will definitely return and order more soup dumplings!

CM6Ovp1t9vJnLdZtjr-5qg.text: Best boba in Pittsburgh!! Love the pork soup dumplings the best, dan dan noodles are delicious and spicy, friends like braised pork noodles (but I'm not a huge fan). Awesome customer service, waiters are all so nice and considerate, owners are really awesome as well.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Soup pork dumplings (best thing on the menu forsure!!!)
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pork belly slider
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Minced pork noodles: delicious

v8f3v9ucVU321a_dZH-q_A.text: As someone who spent a semester in China in college, I can assure you that this place is legit!   The food is piping hot and delicious. I love the noodles, but I must say the dumplings are what had me the most excited. The shrimp wontons are just delightful. I also loved the vegetarian dumplings and hope to try the soup dumplings next time.   I love watching them make them. It's such an art!   The only thing that I wasn't a huge fan of was the chicken soup. The broth was nice but it was pretty much just a boiled chicken wing. I know it's authentic ... just not my favorite thing.   I'd also like to go back and visit again with a larger group as the menu is extensive and there are so many other things I would like to try.   I'm so glad we have a place like this in Pittsburgh! It's so great to have something so authentic have me feeling like I took a trip to the far East.   Give this place a try! You won't regret it.

oi_VedYxyFW93P2xFQOFfQ.text: This place is awesome! I love the stuff there especially the noodles with meat sauce! I haven't tried it all, but I think it's all been exceptional! Everything else is pretty tasty, will write more as I try more!

wiUiJQlmVYzW6eeYTBjfww.text: Good but I wish they had more vegetarian options. What is there is great, just wish there were more choices. Also pretty expensive considering the type of place it is and the nature of the food. But glad they're around.

SR8PDwK_qTy9GtVgRcvdLw.text: We went there Friday night, three days after their grand opening.  The service was attentive and efficient, the decor very comfortable, and the food positively delicious.  Things came out quickly, hot, and delicious.  Better than similar establishments in New York City.   Everything we had was perfect!  We are planning to return regularly!

wPzsHriXiqZ8Qz3ix4rGTA.text: The pork soup dumplings are the best I've had outside of New York City. Plus you can see them making the noodles through the glass window in the kitchen. I will definitely go back.

6uA1W8TahM4cTgQDhotjbw.text: Delicious! The soup dumplings are amazing, the service was great, and the decor is modern. Will definitely be returning.

JQwt02HzSEnmrf9zl25VCA.text: I went for a late lunch on 19 June 2013.  Among other things I ordered the broccoli with vegetable oyster sauce.  It came with chunks of pork on top instead.  Since I am a vegetarian, I asked if they could bring me the veggie version instead, which they did.  But when I got to the bottom of the dish, I found pieces of pork (apprently they just scraped off the pork and re-served it).  When I pointed this out, they offered to bring me a new order, but I asked to have it taken off my bill.  When I got home and checked the bill, they had not removed the broccoli.  Even though the food was quite good, I will personally never go back there because I am upset with their double dishonest behavior.

Z38fopx4w3goXdS1a9TFAw.text: I really, really love noodles! Ever since I was little I've loved noodles & nothing has changed. Watching the noodle makers here stretching & slapping those noodles through the glass totally works for me!   We've eaten here twice now so we've sampled a few dishes: Pickled Cucumber, pork & crab soup dumplings, pork short rib noodle soup, pork buns, Dan Dan Szechwan Dry Noodles, Sesame Cold Noodles with Chicken, etc.  The soup dumplings are the biggest standout, but be advised to pop them open 1st or risk burning your mouth on scalding hot broth inside. They're well worth the wait to let them cool!   Everything I've had is good, although I do tend to agree with others that the portions are so large on the dry noodle and soup dishes that they can become a bit one note before you're finished. Still tasty & taking leftovers home isn't the worst idea.   It's fun and inexpensive to explore their menu. Service has been really helpful & attentive on both our visits. Great little place!

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Dan Dan Szechuan Style Dry Noodles
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pork &amp; Crab Soup Dumplings
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Sesame Cold Noodles with Chicken

Ip7swaufWtLB1y4W0RnVgA.text: I ordered take out from here a few weeks ago and just wasn't super impressed. I was really disappointed because I heard so many great things about this place. They make their noodles from scratch, which is awesome, and they are totally affordable. I tried the dan dan noodles, which were under $8. Maybe it's just not a place for take out, or maybe I ordered the wrong thing. The noodles were very tasty and fresh on their own, but the dan dan sauce was really watery and the flavor was just off from other dan dan noodles I have had. I had to add some peanut butter to the sauce to thicken it up and give it some more flavor. Although I didn't have the best experience, I plan on giving it another try in the future. I plan on trying their pork soup buns, as they seem to be the greatest hit!

8c1KRT9LvFWVT4zGSvg-jQ.text: I like that they make their own noodles here. They taste much more fresh than other noodle placed I've been to. I ordered noodle soup with shiitake mushrooms & bamboo shoots & the portions are HUGE. I didn't realize how much food I was getting whrn I ordered, but I was glad to have 2 meals worth of leftovers. The vegetable dumplings were DELICIOUS, but I think my favorite part was the tofu nuggets. They are little disks of silken tofu, lightly breaded and fried. The outside is nice and crispy & the inside is soft & juicy. Very indulgent. They only have chopsticks & soup spoons to eat with, no forks here, so maybe dont bring someone who has never used them before. The only reason I'm giving 3 stars is because I wish they had more vegetarian options.

gvmAqlK3HmU4nDNfW8vaYQ.text: Hand pulled noodles are hard to make. And honestly this place gets it right. Not to mention their soups are amazing. The only thing I wished was that the soup dumplings were piping dangerous hot. Instead of a dull heat. Overall very nice place.

cfutK_rTx_2mbMflr33miA.text: What a nice surprise! We really enjoyed the authentic handmade noodles, steamed dumplings and "tangbao". They are all fresh and tasty and served in a generous portion and reasonable prices. The staff were all friendly and professional. A "must-eat" place!

sim3Ny2K8qjAhDAuxlPB5w.text: During our trip to Pittsburgh, my friend who goes to college there recommended this place to me.   Being someone from LA, I have high expectations for noodles and asian food in general. And this place did not disappoint. I ordered the beef noodle soup, which had a great broth, quality pieces of beef, and chewy yet tender hand pulled noodles. I love, love, love the texture of the noodles. Even my friends who are from northern parts of China, who have had hand-pulled noodles from their native homeland, loved the noodles.  We also ordered the xiao long bao dumplings and mushroom + bamboo appetizer to share. Those were good, but not spectacular. The bamboo tasted like it was from a can, and had a weird sour taste to it.  Come here and order the noodles! I tried a bit of my friend's zha jiang mian, which was good as well. But my favorite is still the classic beef noodle soup. Would definitely come back here again if I'm ever in Pittsburgh again!

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Beef noodle soup, xiao long Bao dumplings, and bamboo mushroom appetizer

KqM-3FJvfy6VRBo3oR5Xtw.text: Their braised pork belly over rice was AMAZING. I'd say even better than the ones I've had in China. The fatty part of the meat is not greasy at all and literally melts away in your mouth. The pork soup dumplings were not bad either but didn't impress me as much. It was pretty fun to watch them make fresh noodles and dumplings through the glass. The service was great too and all the staff were very friendly.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

QMqR2QqBLnF04MYrJOvVTA.text: Just got back from Taiwan and went to din tai fung (where soup dumplings began and alleged best dumplings in the world).  Din tai fung is delicious, everyday noodles is extremely close!  I love them!!

EFsa5Cklq5WRCZ9paFMXqg.text: I really love the soup dumplings here. Also really cool to see them prepare the food in front of you. The service is also pretty good.   It does get crowded on weekends, had to wait like 5-10 minutes to get seated.

HNIZB1wNyh4RC6kRQpCTvA.text: I always love the Soup Dumplings and the Dan Dan Mian here. If you want to relax and calm down the mind, I recommend their Hot Jasmine Tea. If you want to charge your mind back up again, ready to take on the world or the night, the Flat Noodles in Chilli Oil are the dish to order! :D

s0vU4JkXWaRh_HOnddpGCQ.text: Handmade noodles and dumplings.  Who would have thought that would exist in Pittsburgh.  The best thing to get here is the XLB.  I would have a hard time guessing if it came from here or Din Tai Fung.  FWIW, my parents approve of this place.

FdxHEKSnK6UM5EF6pAhkMA.text: Thin noodle is definitely better than wide noodle. The wide one it too dry and firm. However the beef and tendon are really tasty. Braised pork rice is also really good.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

cF-lBX0JzCyaEp5ezlLF3g.text: Authentic, well-crafted, flavorful dishes. The best noodles in Pittsburgh. There's often a line--but there's a reason. It's worth it.

wfv0Ytfm_RGNVtGXg70j_Q.text: I thoroughly enjoyed my time at everyday noodles. This was my last meal while staying in Pittsburgh and I'm glad we fit this in our schedule.   You write your order down on a sheet using a pencil. Sort of like how a lot of sushi restaurants take your order. We got shumai, pork soup dumplings, scallion pancakes, and some dessert to share. Soup dumplings weren't as good as the ones you'd find in NYC, but still pretty good. Scallion pancake was okay.. decent, but nothing to drool over in retrospect. Highlight of our meal was most definitely the shumai. I usually don't like shumai that much but these were delicious.  The ordering style sort of backfired later, because we decided to get dessert but since we didn't mark it on our sheet, we had to ask for another sheet and wait longer. We got the red bean sesame balls and a coconut jelly dessert. Both were meh. Probably wouldn't order again, but it was nice to try something new regardless.  The kitchen is open with glass so you can see the chefs working and the man pounding and stretching out the noodles was mesmerizing! I'd love to come back and try their noodles.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Shumai
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. XLB
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Dessert

aI0z8P4Pi97GQnh0eOZcqg.text: The only thing hate is their noodle soup went actually in there homemade noodles . That shit was ass but everything else was good tho. I asked Thai tea with no bubble but instead they gave me bubble . Their soup dumplings was good tho

2WVJ6UStZmcrCySZkxNWNg.text: For a college student looking to get some food that was actually decent, I was pleasantly surprised by Everday Noodles. This small restaurant is very busy during lunch and dinner times, but the wait is definitely worth it. The food came very soon after we ordered, and it was absolutely phenomenal. Both the rice and the noodle dishes are really great. I definitely recommend this place if you are looking for some good chinese food, and I definitely will be coming back.

_Mwk0GQGJu8nj2t1w4A5jg.text: Good quality and variety of Asian food. Pork belly Bao is a little too dry. Bubble tea is satisfactory.

UeMxmJo82IcSxBpQPxhwcQ.text: I've been here a few times and each time it's as good as the last. I've tried multiple things off the menu but soup dumplings definitely take the cake as the best item on the menu. I've tried both the pork and the pork/crab soup dumplings and I was very impressed. The flavor is perfect. I've also tried the vegetable dumplings but they weren't as good as the soup dumplings. I've also had the pickled cucumbers and while it sounds boring they are actually very good. It felt like a palette cleanser between all the noodles.   For my entrees I've had the dan dan noodles and the hot spicy wonton noodles. The dan dan noodles had a lot of flavor and sauce which I really liked. The hot spicy wonton noodles on the other hand lacked sauce so it felt very dry. If you don't like very spicy food I also would not recommend this dish. It was a little too spicy for my liking with all the red pepper flakes on it.   Now let's talk about the restaurant itself. It's a cute little restaurant with not much seating so you'll likely have a wait but it's worth it. You can watch them make noodles in the kitchen which is very cool and fun to watch. It's a nice place to go on a date because it's byob and they have a lot of tables for 2 people.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Bubble tea
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Hot spicy wonton noodles to go

i7tGCDBYCARsRStNQrhR5g.text: Reasonable prices and good food.  My fave is Braised Beef Noodle soup- little tiny spicy ness to it, but the broth is super rich and very good. Ive been obsessed and getting this the last 5 times Ive gone here for dinner. Also try the Taiwanese Style Pork Belly Slider- its a giganto Steam bun with pork belly and cucumber and spices, Totes incred.  They make the noodles right on the spot so randomly you may hear the sound of fresh noodles being smashed on the kitchen counters!  Usually I park in the pay to park lot directly behind the restaurant- I've been playing this game called "dont pay the meter ". Its a gamble whether or not ill have a $25 ticket waiting on my windshield after having dinner- but the taste of victory when theres NO ticket on the windshield is almost as good as the food itself! Everyday Noods is def one of my fave spots!

YAZq-4YEgbvQ85FjuCw36Q.text: Try the Dan Dan noodles, any of the wontons/dumplings/buns, and ANY of the appetizers and you will not be disappointed. Affordable and in a very sleek storefront. This place gets busy for a reason- the food is great. I lived in the Bay in Nor Cal for a while and the Chinese/Taiwanese noodles dishes here are as good or better than anything I had in Cali. You even get to watch them make the dumplings and noodles! Shan Dong in Oakland cannot compete with this place!  They have boba tea in coffee, black tea, green tea, taro tea, coffee, and other flavors with all kinds of ad-ins like bubbles, jellies, etc. the black tea with boba is my favorite. So delicious especially when eating a spicy dish!   The wonton spicy noodles are phenomenal- the wontons are shrimp filled and every time I've had them they are delicious. Wide or thin noodles- they are all made in house and are just great!

Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Making noodles!

oWqWSrx4UJCNly23BkSAUw.text: My favorite bubble tea in the city! The tapioca pearls are fresh and sweet and the thai tea flavor is on point. The noodles are fantastic, fresh and made in house! Great place to visit especially in the winter time because the soup bowls are warm and delicious.

O_cqS9oIGBi6OdXCCevoYg.text: This is an experience, not lunch or dinner.   Soak it all in your first time...your going to think about these soup dumpling for the rest of your life.

t2eOD8VqXgfEIrsq6kDLqA.text: Amazing food. Would 10/10 recommend. Had to wait for about 25 minutes for a table. I suggest you make a reservation or show up between lunch and dinner. The soup dumplings are to die for!

HEAurjLGZtp6WZVnvvGKaA.text: My friends and I went in at around 12pm on a Saturday, and it was jam packed! Not too many seating options (and they are pretty close to each other), so we had to wait for 5-10 minutes. We think that they seated a few people ahead of us, too, but that's fine because the food and service afterwards were definitely 5 stars. Lots of options for vegans/vegetarians alike! Their menu has a neat little key. I ordered the only vegetarian option under Dry Noodles, which was Taiwanese Cold Noodles with cucumber on top. Absolutely delicious!! Such a great size, too. I left feeling full but not stuffed. We had gotten the food in under 4 minutes. Servers grabbed our card right away and refilled our waters often. Overall, will definitely come back again, whether that's eating in or doing take-out.   **$15 minimum if using card**

nOaFqn9d1CjLTUbEJQF3nA.text: I had an awesome lunch with my husband, son, and sister and brother-in-law. The hostess was very accommodating and offered us a bench table with a high chair on the end. My 2 year old was right in front of the window where they make hand-pulled noodles and homemade dumplings. The adults had a lot of fun watching too. The entertainment was great, but the food was even better. All of us loved the pork soup dumplings (XLB), the pan fried pork bun, and the green onion pancake. I also tasted the cold noodles - delicious - and the pork belly slider. The pork belly slider wasn't for me (too fatty), but my husband loved it.   Their hospitality really put our experience over the top. Shortly after our food arrived, my son started to get pretty fussy. Unprompted, our server brought over a small ball of noodle dough for my son to play with and pretend he was making noodles. It was a wonderfully kind gesture and I so appreciate their thoughtfulness. We will definitely be going back for the AMAZING food and warm hospitality.

CVrQXZZrMLWPARZSDxbckA.text: PORK SOUP DUMPLINGS are amazing!! Son and I went for lunch on a Sunday. We couldn't decice ehat to order so we over did it: Jelly Fish Salad, Pork Potstickers, Sesame Cold Noodles w. Chicken and Pork Soup Dumplings. I would order everything again but The Pork Soup Dumplings are awesome.

X2e8njnwocfdK06skL2h5g.text: Came here for a big family dinner with 10 people - 8 "young 'uns" and our parents. Between us all we had:  * complimentary pickled cucumber ($4) - okay  * 2 complimentary wood ears & tofu skins ($5) - really good tofu skins  * 1 five spiced eggplant ($5) - eggplant was cooked well but the spicy sauce did nothing for me  * 5 pork soup dumplings ($9) - not the best but probably as good as you can get in Pittsburgh, the skin was nice and delicate - a little too delicate at times as it was hard to get out of the steamer without losing the soup, the filling could be more tender though  * 2 pork & crab meat soup dumplings ($11) - not worth ordering the crab, just stick to plain   * 1 shrimp & loofah soup dumplings ($12) - interesting but again not as good as the plain pork, couldn't really taste the loofah  * 2 vegetable dumplings ($9) - really great filling, probably my favorite dumpling  * 2 rolled onion pancakes w/ sliced beef ($8) - okay, skip this  * 4 pan fried green onion pancake ($6) - meh, skip this  * 4 taiwanese style pork belly sliders($6) - everyone raves about this - including my family - but I didn't get it, the pork belly wasn't very tender though the sliders are huge - more like hamburger size  * 2 noodles with minced pork sauce (zha zhang mian $7) - my favorite dish of the evening but I would expect as much from a restaurants that touts their hand pulled noodles - noodles were very chewy tasty and excellent  * 1 Taiwanese style sesame cold noodles ($6) - didn't like the noodles in this as much  * 2 sweet bean paste crispy pancakes ($7) - awesome, I ate a whole plate  * complimentary creamy crispy mini bun ($4) - my family liked this but it just wasn't to my taste  My picks if I were to come back are in ranked order 1) noodles with minced pork sauce (dry noodles), 2) sweet bean paste crispy pancakes (dessert), 3) vegetable dumplings, 4) pork soup dumplings. 4 stars for these dishes. Skip everything else.  PS My stepmom advises to skip the soup noodles.

G8FJbb4whMJvAOVti5xVYg.text: I went a couple of days ago with my girlfriend and friends and it was amazing!! We ordered pork soup dumplings and I fell in love. It was so unique and truly amazing that they somehow made a delicious and hot soup inside of a perfect dumpling. I would go back just for those! I ordered the pork shrimp wonton noodle soup and it was pretty good as well. I added some chili oil to mine for a bit more spice and it was great, although next time I would order what my girlfriend got, the braised beef noodle soup. That one was even better and had an excellent flavor profile!! The mango bubble tea is also incredible and I go in just for that sometimes. I would definitely recommend this place to anyone!

lAb9_2gVcpOSWmZJljYg3Q.text: The dumplings are to die for! I've gone twice now and the food has been fantastic each time.  The restaurant itself is a small, cute space. That being said, you're always within a food of another table. Private conversations are probably not best had here.   My only complaint was the last time I went, every 30 seconds a chef making dough would SLAM it onto the counter. It sounded like a gun shot. It made the meal really unappetizing when you're jumping every 30 seconds.

bBtzkmfg5k8XnBmFFJzuTA.text: This place has REALLY good noodles! Over the last year, I've been there at least 4 or 5 times, and they don't disappoint! I love asian food, and this place serves very fresh and authentic Taiwanese cuisine. They even make their own noodles and soup buns!

36M1yfYp9eeLxP57vy9UVg.text: Everyday Noodles I was not impressed by your noodles!  I ordered the Dan Dan Noodles and contrary to other reviews I was not pleased. I had the rice noodles and did not expect peanut butter in my hot noodles.  The menu didn't have any description of the dishes which I thought wasn't very customer friendly, but the service was nice! So I suggest that if you want to get something to ask your server first!   The pork dumplings were amazing though, perfectly soupy on the inside and the meat was perfect. They were probably the saving grace of the meal.

NT6r9yrQ4t3sqJfkh3wFNA.text: Jury is still undecided. Jury being me.  I reeeeeally wanted to like it. I love noodles, so with noodles in the name, I expected greatness! I was surprised to only see 12 noodle options with many many other food dishes listed on the menu. There were way more options for soup noodles, but not feeling like soup, I went with the "dry" Dan Dan Noodles with shrimp.   I will preface this by saying, maybe it's just a certain preparation that I'm not used to, but the peanut sauce tasted vinegary to me. Am I crazy? Maybe. But I swear it had a specific taste I could not get past. I honestly couldn't decide if I liked it or I didn't. I came to that realization three days later after I had eaten the leftovers for that amount of time (yes, they give you THAT MUCH FOOD!).   As I said, maybe it's just in the preparation. But I'd like to come back and get some dim sum, or some bubble tea (very limited flavors) or maybe another noodle dish. A girl's gotta do her research, right?!

FHb_hJfn7MvPMqhqSIIoGA.text: We came to Pittsburgh on getaway again because we love the culinary scene of this city. A big part of the trip was to repeat a wonderful experience we had at EN. Unfortunately this time the experience was totally opposite of wonderful. The food tasted MUCH worth, the server was so out of providing a nice and timely service that we had an impression that we are a bother for her. She was mostly ignorant towards us or absentminded to a degree that she wouldn't remember to give us a check and if we wouldn't remind her she'd let us leave without payment for a meal. It was all together a very bad experience.

ty4iVMd3RrVhrXKE3MRF2w.text: At last--handmade noodles and I have been reunited!  This place is straight up legit and I think the majority of the Chinese people in Pittsburgh would agree with me.  You can watch the noodles being pulled by hand through a glass wall.  One mark of authenticity is everyone who works there speaks Chinese.  To my delight, they carry quite a few Taiwanese small dishes.    The BEEF NOODLE SOUP with thin noodles---so good!  The beef shank was oh so tender.  I think I ate the bowl dry.  The PORK SLIDER had a bit too much dough for my liking but it is probably the closest I'm going to come to my beloved gua bao of Taipei without having to fly overseas.  I've also had the SOUP DUMPLINGS and they are tasty but not the best thing on the menu for me.  The MILK TEA is pricey at almost 5 DOLLARS each but it is silky smooth and comes with a variety of toppings.  I'd even say it's better than Rose Tea's across the street!  The place is PACKED every time I've been there and that says a lot for only being open for a few weeks.  Everyday noodle really does leave me wanting to come back every day!  This place is the perfect addition to Squirrel Hill and a one-of-a-kind restaurant in Pittsburgh.

kHCwMK_FTh5mvHU4fC59rw.text: I eat here multiple times a month. The food is consistently affordable, delicious, and served in large portions. Works for a quick lunch or relaxed dinner. I had to post a review just due to the sheer amount of times I've walked out of there completely full and satisfied. Service and atmosphere are always great too!

6VTagyYLtzuL2T3l863Fcw.text: Just go and eat the dumplings please!! I will be back if I ever swing through Pittsburgh again. Amazing!!

g30tOAz_Z5ql3jY5SzjSHg.text: Very good soup dumplings. I got the braised beef soup for my entree, it was full of extremely fatty meat, to the point I had to take it from my soup and tear it apart with my hands. The broth and noodles were really good though, I'd return for something that didn't have beef.

YD49J-v8u2GQqKpi9GE-AQ.text: Managed to grab a table after a 20-minute wait on a Friday night (at 9:30!). We got the pork belly slider again and it was still tasty, though not as amazing as last time. The soup dumplings are as awesome as everyone says, and a pretty good value, especially for Pittsburgh. We also got the spicy wonton noodles, which we enjoyed. We're not big broth fans so we've avoided the "wet" noodle dishes, but the quality might get us to venture out of our comfort zone. Bubble tea was great again.  Tables are rather close together--I have a strong aversion to slurping/mouth noises and this did not serve me well--so it might not be ideal for a date, but we were still pleased with the consistent food quality. Highly recommend takeout to avoid the wait and choose your own spacing!

AwHT3FOZFgVPpE06KqwAMQ.text: Absolutely love this place! It's affordable, and the food is AWESOME. Pork soup dumplings are a MUST get. The wide and thin noodle dishes are great, so are the green onion pancakes. Plus, you get to watch them make noodles and dumplings through glass while you eat. The service is good, it is VERY clean and many Asian's frequent this place (another way to tell if it is good). One of my favorites in Pittsburgh.

z7MZfmJcK3-fGgmvVPVDkQ.text: I came for dinner around 6:30 pm in a party of five on a weeknight. We didn't have to wait very long, but more people started coming in after us. The service was prompt and friendly. Among the five of us, we ordered the pork soup dumplings, vegetable dumplings, spicy wontons, scallion pancakes, shumai, dan tsu noodles (one dry, one with broth), and chicken noodle soup, with wide noodles for all the noodle dishes.  The food was ready pretty promptly, and everyone agreed it was delicious. I had some soup dumplings, which had a great meaty taste. I only wish they served it with some ginger. I also really enjoyed the dan tsu soup noodles. The noodles were "QQ," I appreciated the addition of bean sprouts, and the pork was very flavorful and had a nice balance of lean and fatty meat. The broth itself was lightly flavored. While other reviews refer to the broths' bland taste, I really enjoyed the lightness of the soup. It's also a pretty large portion and worth the price.  Definitely looking forward to returning!

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Lamb Noodle Soup Consommé with wide noodles

wbJEAL7brFe_8hRHMdHUVQ.text: Most amazing food ever!! I wish I could take this gem back to my hometown when my work trip is over!  Pickeled cucumbers...pork dumplings and hot and spicy noodles were delicious!  The service excellent and place is super clean.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Hot and spicy noodles

NkhGsaUfC2HJdIsoq6sCvQ.text: Does it live up to the hype and wait? No, no it doesn't. We came by around 7:45 on Saturday for dinner before catching a movie. There were several groups ahead of us, so it was a 25 minute wait. We weren't pressed, so we waited. I ordered a bubble tea while waiting. Keep in mind they ask for cash or debit for these small purchases. You get boba and two other toppings included in the price.  We entertained ourselves by grabbing a menu and checking what we want. A good way to expedite the process. Also, note that it can get crowded and if it's a rainy night like when we went, the space can be tight.  We were seated and were set to go. Seaweed with garlic to share, dan dan noodles (thin) for hubs, wonton noodle soup (wide) for me. The seaweed with garlic comes and we love the flavor. The balance of sesame oil and garlic was perfect. Our noodles arrived halfway ino the seaweed. I let mine cool off and continue with a couple more bites of seaweed.   Now to the noodles. The wonton noodle soup was a huge disappointment. I'm a serious connoisseur of this of wonton noodle soup, it's a go to staple in my life. Here the broth was bland, very watery, the meat wasn't sitting in long enough for the stock to be flavorful. The noodles were too doughy. It wasn't well represented. The wontons did save it, which leads me to think stay with the dumplings.   The dan dan noodles were not authentic. A peanut flavor was added so the spice wasn't there. It definitely was not what we expected.  So, the saving graces where the seaweed with garlic and wontons. Those items might lure me back in, if in the area, but I won't go out of my way to return.

c9wW7eM0E-4mqk5cmabQAQ.text: AMAZING FOOD! I love their pork soup dumplings and the delicious hot spicy wonton noodles!

TJcjUbrzZH8uQ9Udd_rfvg.text: Love it here!! You can see the chefs making your dishes right there!! Georgie and I have come here multiple times and we love the shu mai.  Actually I love the shu mai, he loves the oxtail soups!   It is always busy so make sure to plan your visit accordingly!

XroU2NwrQXLCeMNhVMuc8A.text: An absolute A+ for effort, value and efficiency.   But the food is much to salty and I suspect loaded with MSG.

hGrCcdfvU2L3AS6JFVxzRg.text: Everyday Noodles offers its customers an enlivening culinary experience. Not only is the decorum modern and colorful, but the entire meal is too! The food is prepared in sight of the patrons: a testament both to their confidence in the food's composition and its freshness. Watching the noodles being made is also fun for any kids, too! The food is a well-prepared, unimposing, tasty Asian cuisine from the hot soup dumplings to the colder noodle salads. For lovers of noodles and all of their complements, Everyday Noodles is a necessity to visit in Pittsburgh!

klD3-eZmOSuJOXDrk9-Sbg.text: Let me start my review by pointing out the obvious - this place is always insanely packed. Every as early as 11 on a Sunday, you may be waiting for a table. Sure sign that they do things right. All the noodles are made in-house as made evident by the busy cooks in the open kitchen concept. You have the option to choose thin or thick noodles. What really gets me through the doors, though, are the vegetable dumplings. Also made fresh in-house daily, I've only ever had the vegetable dumplings but wow are they absolutely incredible! Filled with finely chopped cabbage + other veggies with the perfect dough to filling ratio, these are made perfectly. Crazy, though, that they only have one vegetable noodle entree - and it's a cold season noodle dish topped with thinly sliced cucumber. The flavor is just okay. The only other veggie options include some starters like fried tofu, wood eared mushrooms, etc., or steamed vegetable options. Very few vegetarian/vegan options which is my main gripe. It's a little cramped in there and you're seriously on top of the table next to you. Service is always very quick, though.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Vegetable dumplings are incredible! 10 out of 10. This is what gets me through the door
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

50Ts1xakrdIxPiH6UDTQjg.text: Hand-pulled noodles and good dim sum in Pittsburgh. Good prices. A nice atmosphere. Kid friendly. Need I say more?  Gluten-free dieters should avoid.

ywQjnsOqE4UyipdPd7pA_g.text: Really good dumplings, awesome service. Tried some jellyfish salad. It was really fun, but not that good. The pork bun and pork soup dumplings are to die for. I wish I had one of these in Columbus, Ohio, but we don't haha.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Jellyfish salad, pork bun, pork soup dumplings. Yummy.

87bAx62lBlznBUynV0DiLg.text: Great restaurant, fast service, excellent food. What else can you ask for? We for the dan dan noodle and the beef with tendon noodle soup. Both were really flavorful and the house made flour noodle was great. The noodles were not over cooked, had the perfect tenderness.   we went at lunch and the line was ~10-15 minutes, so just be aware there might be a small wait. I guess when the food is excellent, lines are proof  Attached a few pictures, strongly recommend this restaurant. Will gladly eat here again

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Dan dan
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Braised beef and tendon

2k_MOVtceV8SMfVYlBbAIA.text: Everyday Noodles is a great place for fresh noodles. If it's your first time there, sitting at the bench in front of the cooks is a good show. They have a lot of good dishes. I personally like the Dan Dan noodles and pork soup dumplings.

GC_gWeIJo-EuBMMBNj27qw.text: Noodles I love noodles  so I see a place called everyday noodles I head on in whoa its Thursday about 5:30 pm and the place is rocking people waiting  its a decent sized place with tables along one side and a few bench tables I hear THWACK THWACK and you can see the noodle makers working on the dough THWACK girl at front says would you like take out ? I said no not really ( I want to eat a hot bowl of soup sitting at a table not in my car or drive home and have it cold?) so I said I would like to dine in please  ok so there is a wait  no problem  wait time only 5 min  I get a bench table almost in front of the noodle makers  menu has soups all have meat except the mushroom version  fine thats what I order... they have a full bubble tea menu and I like that  the classic black milk  tea with tapioca bubbles service is prompt and friendly but my 9 dollar bowl of soup was just eh the mushrooms were a bit hard the noddles were just noodles for all that thwacking going on I thought they might be a bit more then just plain old noodles at 9 dollars for a bowl I can say eh it wasn't worth it (it was big but ...) the bubble tea was pleasant but the bubbles should have had a bit less hardness to them. so end of bowl ...not sure I would return  plus parking was hard to find

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Mushroom noodle soup
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Bubble tea

PDus1DOhhuXggfa1xdpKqw.text: I moved here from the West Coast a few months ago and had been looking for a good xiao long bao fix. Lo and behold, Everyday Noodles had raving reviews about them and now I see why. I was also a fan of the scallion pancake. Coming back soon for sure.

Wue3CZIXbNEUj-BYBimqcg.text: I ordered $400 of food from here. Ordering on the phone was very easy, the lady was very helpful. The food arrived warm and exactly on time. They also included chopsticks/napkins/utensils, something a lot of restaurants don't seem to do.   Overall I had a very good experience ordering from Everyday Noodles and would do so again.

_OTTLW1WmcLQafFlfcCPVQ.text: Everyday Noodles noodles are so fresh you can literally stand and watch the chef make them in the restaurant. They're incredibly delicious and a must try. Also get some soup dumplings and a bubble tea while you're here.

rXlcoKmx835Cuy18o9taMw.text: I had the pickled mustard greens and pork noodle soup and the pork soup dumplings. The noodles were great and I could see them making them in the back while we ate. The broth was good, but not great. I loved the soup dumplings. Each one was like a little bowl of soup with all the flavors you would expect. I would go again just for those dumplings and maybe try another noodle dish.

nHNKpPSQzLSHFFBh0Nl3GQ.text: This place gets 5 stars on the pork soup dumplings alone!   This is one of my favorite local BYOB spots! I could fill myself on the pork soup dumplings, they are literally amazing and you must drizzle the chili oil on top for an extra kick!   The menu is large and very reasonably priced so you won't break the bank trying out a bunch of different things! I love the noodle soups and the dry noodle dish as well, they aren't afraid to use spice!   You can watch the chefs making the homemade noodles as well, its a really cool atmosphere. If you haven't tried bubble tea this is one of the places where you can get a really good one!

atiB2QMbhagj79GhiPJAyA.text: Good portion sizes! Affordable,  and very fresh food. My fiance is Asian and she loved it. I tried duck egg for the 1st time here and it was really just like a regular chicken egg. The servers are quick and the ladies that sit you are very friendly. Solid location in the middle of squirrel hill, highly recommended.

Lw8JzlTnJjLTLIIpKsjzyg.text: Went here at 4:30 pm on a Saturday while visiting my daughter, who lives in Squirrel Hill. It was completely packed and we soon found out why: hands down the best noodle place I have ever been. Everything was amazing but the green onion pancakes were delectable, and I have never ever had a potsticker with such a delicate skin and wondrous flavorful filling. I'll be back.

NN_-QOkXVNVh3clG9vimDw.text: Pittsburgh first-timer here! My second stop on my first -time visit to Pittsburgh.  Came here for peak dinner hours and ended up waiting maybe 10 min tops. The service is very fast. It is a pretty small restaurant, with seating close together, so if you're not accustomed to sitting a little closer to strangers, or are looking for an intimate seating arrangement in which you can have quiet dinner talk, this would not be the place to take your date. BUT, if you ARE looking for amazing noodles and dumplings at decent prices, then this IS the place for you!  For appetizer, we got the rolled onion pancakes with sliced beef. I think it is a well put together, fresh dish. For main course, I ordered the spicy braised beef noodle soup. Just the perfect amount of spicy. The broth was rich and dark with deep undertones of the beef. The beef was so tender that it just pulled apart. The noodles were soft with just the right amount of texture and chew. We also got an order of pork soup dumplings. These things were little pockets of flavor in your mouth.   For dessert, we really wanted bubble tea. But because they had run out of boba, we got to pick one other filling from the list. I got taro milk tea with caramel pudding. My boyfriend got taro milk tea with mango pudding. They were both pretty good.   Will definitely make a return to Everyday, someday (;

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Braised beef spicy noodles
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Soup dumpling

ClRrY98_-TpYxSA11xx6qA.text: Best scallion pancake ()I ever had!  Hot and crunch yet "meaty" enough.  The pancake with red bean paste ()and Steamed dumplings ()are really good too.  The only one I am not totally thrilled is the pork and shrimp wonton soup ().  Love to try their other food next time visiting Pittsburgh.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Red bean paste crispy pancake
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Steamed dumplings and pork/shrimp wonton soup
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Last piece of scallion pancake

s3gx9e4dfO-DXz7Jl4SPcQ.text: I love this place!! I have been coming to Everyday since its opening week back in 2013 (I believe) when my Taiwanese and Chinese friends took me. They believed it to be one of the more authentic Chinese restaurants in Pittsburgh at the time. Since that first time, I have tried (and enjoyed): - five-spiced eggplant [5/5] - pork soup dumplings [5/5] - braised beef (& tendon) noodle soup [5/5] - broccoli [4/5] - baby bok choy [4/5] - pork potstickers [5/5] - pan fried green onion pancake [4/5] - taiwanese style pork belly slider [4/5] - pan fried pork bun [4/5] - braised beef (& tendon) over rice [5/5] - noodles with minced pork sauce [5/5] - milk tapioca pearl bubble tea (various) [5/5]  I have to say this place has been consistent every time I have gone (I have ordered the items above multiple times which has unfortunately made me maybe miss out on some of the other great things on the menu but alas, I just love the above so much that I can't help but order them time and time again). The interior is generally quiet and you can get a good look at how the noodles are made depending on where you sit. I highly recommend coming here if you are interested in trying authentic Chinese food!!

faohSUezOqLXufIPVQkVXQ.text: This is by far the best Asian restaurant in town. The food is to die for and is authentic. My go to order for two people is pork soup dumplings, pork buns, and Dan Dan noodles. I tried their soup dumplings more than 2 years ago and they immediately became my favorite food. Also, you get to watch the noodles being made through a glass wall. Warning- there is almost always at least a 10 minute wait because the food is just that good. I would recommend this restaurant to anyone who likes Asian cuisine.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

FwrJk3J3Rcj2Bjiw9UbogA.text: The beef noodle soup are great and the  are okay. Overall I like this place a lot and will be come back and try more dishes.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

QJi3nVgxoMZmqjbYhS5OJA.text: We ran into Everyday Noodles on a Saturday afternoon right before they closed before dinner (they do that open til 2:30, reopen at 4:00 thing).  The place itself is really cute. Tables and bench seating and a huge window to watch the guys make your noodles and dumplings--a la Eat N Park bakery style.  Biggest take away:  it smells weird in here. Couldn't figure out what exactly.  I had the cold sesame thin noodles and +1 got the vegetable dumplings.  My noodles were out instantly with a heavy peanut-y sauce, pulled chicken, and tons of cucumber.  The noodles themselves were incredible, but I thought it was taken over by how intense the peanut was.  Now I did love the sauce; sweet and creamy with a tiny spice, but way too much. +1 thought this was a selling point, but I'm gonna stick with Ramen across the street for this dish still.  The dumplings were incredible though.  I'm hearing that's why people go here.  The soup dumplings are supposedly infamously delicious but they don't have any Erin diet friendly ones so I can only speak for the streamed veggie.  The flavor was much richer than I expected or am used to, mushroom heavy and soft without the mushy veg-paste you sometimes get.  I'm pretty into these little guys.  I also had a mango milk bubble tea which I was seriously unimpressed with (and passed on to the lactose intolerant +1).  In general, I'm a fan.  There are few places like this around. I love the quality and the authenticity but wasn't all about it.   They deliver for free within five miles (which includes S'Liberty, woo) so I might have some dumplings in house soon but not sure if it'll be my first choice on Forbes.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Vegetable dumplings + cold sesame noodles

YR5_-IcRbv3GxX4myWofSw.text: Best boba in Pittsburgh! Their black milk tea has a unique flavor that isn't overly sweetened or watered down, unlike some other places. I also love their green milk tea (matcha), which is a bit thicker than regular milk teas. One downside is that it's cash only for orders under $15, but that has never stopped me from coming back!

bg_N0eOopMnAqzvYvlI-aA.text: Fantastic soup dumplings, pork buns, noodle soups and pork belly! Great service. Would give it six stars if we could.

MgH7Qmk7WQ5KHD23eoGJtA.text: Popular place.  We were told 25 minute wait and it was a few minutes less. It is a little loud. They seem to move tables fast.  Our waitress was OK.  She did explain one item when asked but just seemed to be in a hurry.  Our food did come out fast but not all together.  One person was done when the last meal come out.  I get that most share and we did share some items but the last meal received was for someone that was not sharing.  We were given some take away containers before being asked and before being done...I guess we were at the table to long! Ha! With so many reviews and pictures will keep this short.  The potstickers and Soup Dumplings we had were very good.  We had the drucken chicken to start and it was a little to cold from sitting in a cold refrig. We were there on a Sunday when they are suppose to have Shrimp w. Loofah Soup Dumplings but it was not available...we were there for an early dinner so not sure if it was available that day or not.  We had some steamed broccoli with the minced pork sauce that was cooked perfectly and very good.  I am a fan of the food but the rush to get you out and the lack of any real service was strange!  So do take out!

jEMVQN2d60VmUSAX5VsZeg.text: The food here is AMAZING! You can't leave without getting the Taiwanese pork buns or the dumplings. Service is friendly and fast. Our food was delicious and prices are so reasonable...delicious food even if you're ballin on a budget. I will definitely be back!

7hGMkx-f5cmYF03OrvMHrQ.text: First impression is that the restaurant is very cute. Definitely modern style but an obvious Asian inspiration with bamboo, wood, and dark tiles. The focal point when you enter is of course the window looking into the kitchen where you can see people hand drawing noodles and making dumplings. It's awesome to watch and there are two tables right in front you can have dinner and a show. All thought loud, it's pretty amazing their precision and strength.   PORK SOUP DUMPLINGS -- As the only place in Pittsburgh to get some xiao long bao, they're pretty decently price and good for the price. $9 a basket (8 to an order) is a pretty good price for having a monopoly on the market. They're filled with just enough soup and the broth is well flavored. I thought they were a bit skimp on the pork filling to be honest and the dumpling size is a smidge smaller than I would have preferred. When they come out they're nice and hot though and they provide boy the soy/vinegar sauce and ginger garnish for the dumplings. Best when hot, so don't leave them off for too long. All in all - I have had better, but I have definitely had worse. Would get again in Pittsburgh.   MARINATED BEEF SHANK --  Pretty good. Not sure what kind of sauce is drizzled over the lettuce garnish but it's a nice little something. The beef reminds me of the meat you get with pho and really sparks the craving for some. The meat was tender and they give you a pretty good helping for an $8 appetizer. Topped with green onions - it's a pretty good starter.   TOFU SKIN --  Generally not a fan of tofu skins and that didn't differ this time. There was a lot left to the imagination and a lack luster experience. I would not get this again. It's similar to eating jelly fish, no flavor. It could be better/improved with a spicy sauce of sorts in my opinion.   BRAISE BEEF NOODLE SOUP -- I didn't get it this time, but the first time I went to Everyday Noodle this is what I ordered. It was a very healthy portion for $11. The handmade noodles are really good. Being their main focus I would expect nothing less. They give a very good amount of meat per serving so I think the $11 price is justified. I thought the broccoli was a bit odd...there are much better choices for veggies in soups like baby bok choy or something. But good no less. I would recommend this dish. I've had the dan dan noodles and some others, but I would argue to say braised beef is my favorite.   I am pretty loyal to Rose Tea for my boba, but will admit Everyday Noodle has some delicious black milk tea. Their tapioca isn't as good, kind of hard, but that could be that they're older. I will admit that I like their variety in toppings like red bean, green bean, puddings, and jellies. I can't speak for their other flavors, but if you want boba then I suggest the black milk tea.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Black milk tea w/ red bean, boba, and coconut jelly
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pork soup dumplings
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Marinated beef shank

2EYBQVaIMC3HBWmUmBbk7A.text: Amazing, authentic dim sum!!  Would highly recommend the Xiao Long Bao,  Dan dan noodles, Braised beef noodle soup, and red bean pancakes to finish off. Freshly made and great service - don't be afraid to ask the waitresses or waiters if you aren't too sure about the menu. Come early to avoid lines though!

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Xiao long baos and red bean pancakes

awThxbHEfJl73QZkfxkYdw.text: Soup dumplings. Nuff said.  And if soup dumplings in the middle of Pittsburgh isn't enough to sell you, they also have chefs hand pulling the noodles right in front of you.

h3hSY4hwxeU7fqV488yFUA.text: Yum! The dumplings are really good. We enjoyed everything we ordered. The service was fast and efficient and we never ran out of water.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Veggie dumplings
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Yum! Pork dumplings!
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. My serving of braised beef over rice. So tender!

8seJINV9o3OoW7VfOdh5QQ.text: I've been to this place many times. The first time I went was the first time I ever had soup dumplings.   Let me tell you, if you've never had soup dumplings you've never experienced what I believe is one of the few perfect bites of few food you could possibly have.   These dumplings are actually soup filled along with a pork or otherwise meaty meatball. They are amazing.   Now here's why this place gets five stars from me. Everything else I've had on their menu has been 100% solid and very repeatable (consistent).  Some of the top side dishes I've ever had anywhere are the drunken chicken (a cold sliced chicken terrine with goji berries and some type of wine maybe?).   Their fried silken tofu is also totally awesome. Crispy on the outside and silky smooth on the inside.   Their cucumber salad is ridiculously good, yet simple, and I applaud the use of a certain amino acid that may or may not have been added here.   I've had the shumai here also, which are high end, large, and very meaty.   I've also had the pork belly buns, they're larger than I've typically seen, and as always spectacular.   So, to recap, tons of awesome food that is good every time. Five stars. Hands down.

3p53WLwKiC7AlXISVeciWQ.text: Amazing! I would even go as far to say this place is comparable to Din Tai Fung in SoCal. Came here for lunch and it was crowded but the wait was minimal. Servers were attentive and we ordered as soon as we sat down. Food came out quickly and was paced so that our table for two wasn't ridiculously crowded with food and no room to eat. Loved the beef scallion pancake rolls despite being an eater who shuns greasy fried foods (it wasn't greasy at all!). Flavorful shumai and xlb as well as the pork noodles. Love the hand drawn noodles. So amazing! I'm drooling all over again!

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pork noodles. Good alternative to soup noodles for a summer day.
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Do not miss the beef wrapped scallion pancake. Not greasy and amazing. Like an Asian &#34;burrito&#34; gone perfectly right
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Xlb. Got the one with pork and crab. Very delicious but save yourself a buck and get the pork.

ftlyDzjAKhRv1QzEuvHDsA.text: I LOVE LOVE LOVE this place! Sometimes noodles are the only thing that will do, and EN nails it. Highly recommend the pork soup dumplings, like nothing I had ever tried before- the soup & pork are completely contained within each dumpling, and it's like a wonderful explosion in your mouth. The gyoza dumplings are the best I've ever had, plus the way they prepare them is interesting too.... they're all pan fried together then served flipped over on a plate still attached, resembling an omelet. BYO with a $5 corkage fee, not too shabby. Definitely check this place out!

Y3A_ltvnuVKEvtmNNqBAvA.text: This noodle restaurant is in my opinion, one of the best restaurants in Pittsburgh.   Positives: +absolutely delicious food +fresh hand made noodles +fast and courteous service +don't know where else to get such awesome soup dumplings +best bubble tea in Pittsburgh +fun and unique desserts  Negatives: -smaller space so it gets crowded very easily -a bit on the pricier side, expect to spend around $20 for an entree, app and drink and $9-11 for just entree -long waits during prime time -not vegetarian or vegan friendly and not for people who don't eat pork (sorry!)  Recommend: +any of the bubble teas, I usually get the milk green tea +soup dumplings are a must +my favorite noodles are the sesame cold noodles with chicken +if you're feeling adventurous, try the wood ears and tofu skins as an app +potstickers are a classic and super crispy +the braised beef noodle soup is very authentic and delicious. Also a large portion +try one of the desserts, you won't be disappointed +my personal favorite is the sweet egg yolk steamed bun, which has a gooey inner sweet filling and a fluffy outer bun shell

wyTSmMelPK947GVwQs_ABg.text: We arrived at around 5:30pm and had to wait like 30mins. When we were seated though, they got our food ready in around 5min. Amazing :)  Don't forget to get the soup dumplings,  they're great!

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Soup dumplings are yum :)

zypV9QVaL0FOg8VBoVvwHA.text: I went with family.  We ordered mango milk tea,  braised beef soup with rice noodles, cold sesame noodles with rice noodles, pork and vegetable potstickers,  and pork soup dumplings.    Everything was served quickly in a friendly manner. I loved my soup dumplings and potstickers.  My sister thought the sesame noodles needed more flavor. My mother thought her braised beef soup was too spucy-hot; I tried it. It was ordered to be mild and it was.  Plenty of leftovers to take home. It was nest to watch dumplings and noodles being made.  The parking was difficult to find and the check arrived a bit slow. All in all, a very delicious and wonderfully unique dining experience.

Pl-n90UpMqmOGemJJUO8Ig.text: The beef braise noodle soup is prolly the gem of this restaurant. I ordered their xlb and it wasn't the best I've had. The xlb ive had in houston and din tai fung are better.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

bosvMlYEtLpiQMl4A8leqQ.text: Per my Taiwanese friends' recommendation, we took my mom, who is a "dough-snub" (see my review Szechuan Gourmet) to Everyday Noodles. We came on Saturday at 11:30am. There was no wait. Like good tourists, we took the seat right in front of the "performance window". My mom spent more time watching than eating, so the premium seating is totally worth it. ---------- We ordered:  - Beef tendon: My personal favorite out of all we ordered. So soft. So gelatinous. Beefy. On my next visit I MUST order this.  - Woodear mushroom & flat tofu: Has goji berries. Flavorful. This is my friends' fave.  - Seaweed: Also flavorful and soft. This dish is cooked thoroughly so it's very soft. Not much chewing is required.  - Pork belly slider: My dining buddy's fave. It reminds him of the Thai dish Kao Kar Moo (minus the buns).  - Milk tea: My dining buddy prefers the milk tea at the Taiwanese joint in Cleveland (Phusian Cafe). Has more tea aroma.  - Pork Soup dumplings: Awesome (for Ohio and PA). Must order.  - Pork & crab dumplings: My dining buddy's fave. Although my mom claimed she saw them took the dumplings out of the refrigerator - meaning this is not made fresh, as the Pork Soup dumplings are. Regardless, good flavor as well. ---------- My mom chatted with the owner for a good half an hour. He hired the head chef straight from Taiwan, who also made dumplings and noodles at a reputable Taiwanese restaurant.   On our Pittsburgh trip, we went to two restaurants owned by Taiwanese. Both places prioritize health over heavy-handed seasoning (meaning reduced sodium, sugar, fat, msg). From what I've heard from the Taiwanese joint in Cleveland, that's a total of three owners, all in favor of such philosophy. So maybe that's the trend in the Taiwanese culinary service industry. I approve. And I've never felt the flavors were sacrificed in any way.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pork &amp; crab meat dumplings
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pork soup dumplings
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pork belly slider

GW-dIIaKee-auUmabQpCUQ.text: My initial comments were based on delivery to my home. Since then, I have dined in the restaurant.  There is SO much that is good about this place. It starts with the homemade noodles; they have what Italian cooks call great "tooth feel," meaning the homemade texture stands out and highlights the sauces.  For the Dry Noodle and soup dishes, you will have a choice of thin or wide noodles. I prefer the latter with sauces and thin noodles with soup.  A number of Dry Noodle dishes use an authentic Chinese sesame sauce, which is less creamy than mid-Eastern tahini sauces. Toss, give the sauce time to coat the noodles and you'll like it.   The soup dumplings are delicious; the veggie dumplings are good but a little bland.  Ask for shredded ginger and chili sauce to spice things ups.  From the Dim Sum menu, try the Pan Fried Onion Pancakes with Sliced Beef which are impossibly good. Many of the appetizers are palate refreshing, like the pickled cucumber and five spiced eggplant. There are four selections using rice. I have tried and liked Braised Beef over rice, which has a tasty gravy, infused with Chinese five-spices seasoning.   Finally, this restaurant offers real value to its customers.  Most dishes are under $10.00.  You easily get four dishes, which is enough to feed 3-4 people, for under $40.00.

bNe6c43mku4mzvpEHh8dXA.text: This place is a must go if you are a fan of pork soup dumplings.   They have a cool bench/window area where you can watch the chefs make the noodles and dumplings. The noodle making process is really fun to watch.  I love their bubble milk tea!  The price is a little expensive for what you get.

TNp1aGZWL3VgocaQ2TkYlw.text: I am a self-proclaimed foodie-- I love reading about food, cooking food-- and of course eating food. When I was planning our weekend trip to Pittsburgh, naturally food would be a big part of our experience.  We dined at some delicious spots over the 3 days in town-- but loved Everyday Noodle SO much that we ate two meals there!!  The soup dumplings do not disappoint! The first night I had the beef and dry noodle and my husband had the spicy wonton noodle. We both enjoyed our meal-- but he may have out-ordered me.  The second meal, I had the shrimp and pork wonton soup and he had the spicy wonton dry noodle again. This time we went with the wide noodle instead of the thin. We both thought the wide-noodle was better. My shrimp and pork wonton had potential, but it lacked flavor. My soup was a very watery-bland broth. It could have benefitted from some sodium and it would have been nice to have some fresh, whole shrimp in the soup as well.  We have both had better pulled noodles in other cities-- (comes down to the broth) but it was still a huge treat for us!   Bottomline: highly recommend!

pV0vgAmXdv-0d20Gu607Pg.text: I wanted to like this place so much more than I actually liked it.  Food: quality? Pretty darn fresh. My noodles were bland though! That was totally unexpected since this is a noodle store. I liked the texture very much and their house hot sauce but it definitely wasn't flavorful enough.  Service: no complaints but didn't wow me  Novelty: high! The chefs from Beijing make the noodles behind glass and it's fun to watch. However, it can also be jarring after a while to keep on hearing that loud thud when they slam the dough on the cutting board.  Price: way too high for a small noodle eatery. The scallion pancake appetizer was $7 EACH. You need at least 5 of them for a meal. It's highway robbery.   Portions: TINY. I have never been hungry after eating a bowl of noodles at a restaurant so I guess there's a first time for everything. I finished my tiny-ass bowl of bland noodles and went home for a second meal and dessert to feel satiated. C'mon, now.   I might recommend hipsters to go here but probably will not make the trip myself again.

p4sQfvt8ydONzH8nRD-YHg.text: The food  here is okay only because Pittsburgh lacks a lot of really good Chinese restaurants. Place is kind of expensive, especially since the cost of the ingredients they need to make the kind of food they make is pretty cheap. But I guess you can apply that to many of the Chinese restaurants here.  Jellyfish Salad - Probably one of my favorite things here. Like the garlicy taste but again really expensive. Don't think the small plate is worth $8.  Five spiced Eggplant - Also liked this one. Sauce is kind of ketchupy and vinegary.  Braised Beef Noodle Soup - Beef is really delicious, tender, and flavorful. Soup is kind of flavorless. Doesn't have the "Beef Noodle Soup" taste like ones in Taiwan. Had this twice. The first time the noodles were overcooked. Second time they were better and were more QQ.  Braised Minced Pork over Rice - Tastes like how I make it except has no ginger or shallot flavor, so pretty good.  Dandan noodles - This did not taste good. Was not spicy and tasted like peanut butter and vinegar??  Zha jiang mian - My favorite thing there. The sauce and meat are delicious.  I never had their Xiao Long Bao, but my sister said the frozen ones you buy at the Asian supermarket taste better.
