-PGrkMHjkS1ROFSopHjNIg.text: I love this place. The food is well made and I don't feel bad afterwards. I've been here several times and I'm never disappointed. Their soup dumplings really hits the spot. Only thing is that I wish they had some new items to keep their customers on their toes! Traditional Taiwanese small eats and street foods! Bring them!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pork soup dumplings! Sooo juicy. Have some vinegar with it. Best way to eat

0q0RVXrOWZdXk6j3dDmBrw.text: LOVE!!! I am from the Bay Area, and so I am picky about this stuff. Amazing, Amazing food!!   The potstickers are off the charts and #48 is the best darn bowel of noodles I have had in a while. The staff are really great as well and super friendly and efficient.   Oddly got the recommendation for this place from my Chiropractor! So happy he mentioned it! Will be back all the time for sure :)

pEkfWsoTaG14-yZXrrk2bQ.text: This place is the best taiwanese/chinese food I've had in Pittsburgh so far. Four of us went and we sat at the long table in front of the window so we got to watch as they made soup dumplings and noodles.   The pork soup dumplings were amazing. Just the right amount of ginger to give it the extra flavor.    We also had the dan dan noodles, very much a peanut-style sauce, so if you're not a huge fan of peanut flavor, you might want to pass. (I loved it)   Next, we had the potstickers, pork, shrimp and crab shumai, and beef noodle soup. The soup had large pieces of beef, was very tender, and really flavorful. We had the rice with minced pork, pickled cucumbers and I had a green milk tea.  Highly recommend. Expect a 30 min wait, but well worth it!

ajXTcK8L-qpCGOgHe_5XMw.text: Fresh noodles, Fresh Noodles, FRESH NOODLES!!  Then I saw how long the line was and thought "OH this place is going to be good!"  First being the soup dumplings! They really should have a diagram on how to eat these little morsels. I was presented with a bamboo steamer with dumplings, a side of ginger and vinegar, and a soup spoon. Okay? Luckily my friend who was with me showed me how to eat them. It was slightly embarrassing but enlightening. Google it if you are unsure how. The flavor is mellow yet delicious. The combination of ginger, vinegar, and soup gives this appetizer that great Umami taste!  Just don't wait too long to eat them or else they will dry out.  Braised Beef Soup Noodles: The soup was very good and flavorful. The beef has a lot of tendons in it (not my favorite type of beef) but overall good. You have the option of getting Rice or flour noodles (wide or thin).  I like the flour noodles best. The rice noodles are light and thin; breaks apart easily. The flour noodles are more dense. It all depends on your preference.  Oxtail Soup Noodles: I LOVE OXTAIL! Just sad that the oxtail they serve was small. But it sufficed my oxtail needs. You know it's cooked well when it falls off the bone. That's all I have to say about that!  Pork Belly Slider: Not my favorite. 1) Too large 2) Dry bun 3) dry pork It would be so much better and presentable if they made several small portions of the slider and served it that way. Or just make a bun instead. The steamed slider should be fluffy, like you are biting into a delicious cloud. Instead it had hard pieces like it was overly steamed. Lastly the pork wasn't that good, it was so dry.  Service/Space: The service is fast and friendly. No complaints. There are some communal seating by the noodle makers. The restaurant space is very tight yet clean. It reminds me that I am in the city and I like that.  Overall, I love this place. I'm definitely a fan! And can't wait to try more dishes!

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Hot and spicy wonton noodles
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pork soup dumplings. It really has soup in them. I did not know that!
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Gotta have my jasmine tea

NoEfMfNtEr3jvXaw7o_Eyw.text: Everytime I come here the wait staff is friendly and timely if get the chance to watch them cut the dough for noodles do it it's pretty cool I highly recommend the pork soup dumplings they are outta this world

qT6OwcmTK0ZkMgMki8F08A.text: Average noodle place, honestly nothing special even though they make their own noodles.  The xiao long bao are really overpriced, $9 for 6 or 7 of them? But they are good.  Bubble tea in my opinion is so no good. They put too much milk in it, bubbles are good, but also too sweet. If we ever go here we eat there and get bubble tea across the street @ Rose Tea Cafe.  I've had their beef noodle soup, which was good and their Dan Dan noodles (eh)  Interior design is nice, very modern. However, the seating space is rather small and there are usually long waits (depending on what time you go).  Good for college students or people going out with their friends

wPIsPnvkjDct268pkLkkgQ.text: Came to this restaurant unexpectedly. My boyfriend and I were just looking for a quick place to eat and stumbled in with not very high expectations. This place was surprisingly great! The restaurant interior has a good vibe, a great music playlist, the cooks handmake the noodles, and the staff was very friendly. The menu is pretty simple, but has great options. We started with the shrimp, pork, and vegetable wontons which came with mung bean noodles. These were DELICIOUS!!! My boyfriend then got the dan dan noodles Szechuan style. These were great and filling. I got the braise minced pork over rice. This was great and the portion was very large for the price of only 7$! I am very pleased with my visit and will definitely come back again.   Ps: I am even happier to see that this place delivers!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

5snkYFX0RLtlfSIbJ-klcQ.text: Nice atmosphere, good quality and fast service. I will definitely be back. We arrived at 6:15 and only had to wait 10 minutes. We were seated right in front of the noodle making window and it was very enjoyable. The service was super fast and the pork soup dumplings were delicious as was the beef noodle soup (noodles were wonderful). The party of three I was with ordered bubble tea which was very good as well.   Overall it was a very enjoyable experience and I highly recommend eating here.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Nice atmosphere!
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pickled cucumbers

C9hVPraf9WCbEvMDytqoDQ.text: Delicious fresh noodles. Food will come to your table fast. Always packed with people. Good bubble tea.

-6fXEi9Ps-YaA7sJkmFM-w.text: To say I love this place would be an understatement. All the main staples you'd expect to find are right there for the taking. I've tried a fair amount on the menu and have yet to be disappointed. The pork belly sliders, dim sum and soup dumplings are a must. If you plan on going past 5 be prepared to wait. Prices are fair for what you get and the staff is very helpful

YeY2jzuvlywqJe_gZoOKSA.text: Real authentic Chinese food. Been to many places in New York, this is one of the best!

sMQ2HZoHhhgWSDw_NwpR-g.text: Forever tired...hungry and broke...sighhhhh  iv been craving some Asian food during my trip to Pittsburgh...Got take out and the food was just bland and mediocre...  Why would everybody go to this restaurant and only buy one or a few things when you can go to a buffet with the same quality food....the quality is just bad !!! same prices and have access to all the food at this restaurant...their highlight dish... steam soupy dumplings were kinda disgusting,...i had way better dumplings then this...very disappointing...everything was just bland and tasteless!  they wouldn't even deliver to my hotel room because they felt like four miles was too far....i would think since i purchased sixty dollars worth of foods they wouldn't have a problem delivering...but whatever...never ordering here again!

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. My life be like...

51froel_rfNPxnICH-LW4w.text: As a Squirrel Hill resident, I can't believe I didn't try this place earlier! I went with a couple of friends on a Sunday and they said it was a 30 minute wait. However, it was a lovely day out, so we asked if we could sit outside. Turns out, you can sit outside if you get take-out AND there's no wait! I don't know why more people didn't want to sit outside. We got to experience a beautiful spring day, and it was way quieter outside than it was inside.   Anyways, the food was great! I am a huge fan of Taiwanese food. Having gone to Taiwan a couple of times because my extended family lives there, I thought the food we got was pretty authentic and delicious. I got the cold Taiwanese noodles. Since we got it to-go, it came with the noodles and cucumbers in one container, and the soy sauce, peanut-y sauce, and ginger each in their own containers. Everyone who tried my noodles loved them. My friends also got the braised beef noodle soup dish and one other noodle dish. Everyone raved about how good the food was. We also got some pork soup dumplings to share. They were ok (not the best I've had, but passing for soup dumplings). I definitely plan to come back!

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. The cold Taiwanese style noodles - thick noodles with peanut-y sauce, ginger, and thinly sliced cucumbers. So good.

PUSFuWDhWYooF2zOSGRlYQ.text: Amazing noodles and the cold dishes were delicious too. Fast service and all the food tasted authentic. Would come back many times if I lived in Pittsburgh!

HAWjLyCWd9mbphCSt2tEhA.text: After 8 years of trying nearly every restaurant the city has to offer, I can confidently say that Everyday Noodles is the best restaurant in Pittsburgh by far. The staff is amazing, the kitchen is consistent, the prices are cheap for the quality, the service is always incredibly fast, and the food is to die for. I have been a weekly customer for years and upon leaving Pittsburgh, it will be the thing I miss most about my city.  My ideal feast for two is as follows: - taro bubble tea with double lychee jellies - cucumber appetizer to start (no. 2 fave) - pork soup dumplings (no. 1 fave) - pork & vegetable potstickers - steamed bokchoy with veg oyster sauce - egg yolks buns for dessert (Keep in mind this is a feast level of food for 2)  Some of my other favorite menu items: - five spice eggplant - steamed broccoli - steamed iceberg (surprising but so good!) - scallion pancake - pancake with sliced beef - dan dan noodles - both of the dry sesame noodle dishes - sesame rice balls  I'm not a big fan of broth soups in general, so they don't make my list of faves but honestly everything here is sooo delicious. I do not recommend this place for vegetarians just because I find the meat dishes to be out of this world but you can totally make it work for people with all dietary needs!  Thanks for all of the delicious meals, Everyday Noodles! I will miss you guys! I am drooling writing this review. I love love love Everyday Noodles with my whole heart and belly. Give them a chance and find a new fave!

ZkiIm6iJt6L-aFrUnsECeQ.text: It's all about the food here! We all know that all food is subjective, but I spent six months touring China , and this is as close to the real deal ( noodle dishes) as I have ever had. I stuck with anything noodles, and avoided the soups. The noodles are authentic and the potstickers which are more Japanese were perfect. The soup dumplings are a must. I might also add ... no heart burn. This place is super clean with unassuming service. Friendly, happy and hospitable staff greeted you at the door. The servers knew the menu which isn't the case everywhere.  You will forget you are in the USA You will love this restaurant! Xie Xie

ITAzTXdRAGpuUzGBqGI8eQ.text: I had to get carry out bc of work and time constraints but I was very impressed by how quickly they had it ready. The vegetable steamed dumplings were fire  and so were the dan dan noodles (tip: use some chili oil to spice them up if you're into that). Their black milk tea is authentically brewed and definitely not powdered.   This place is really comparable to the notorious din tai fung (Taiwanese restaurant) minus the annoying lines. A jewel hidden inside Squirrel Hill.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

QEEt6m65Xw_ck7KY-qL21g.text: Everyday noodles is an incredible place. If you are hungry, and also want to watch your noodles being made in front of you, come here. My old zaydie used to say, "it's better than tv"

3pyufUTGZ7oPE1R_ajNQgA.text: We went there for lunch and enjoyed a very friendly and speedy service! I started with the soup dumplings which were very good--freshly made-- and I will definitely take them again on my next visit. The Dan Dan noodles Szechuan style were very good and flavorful. However, personally I wouldn't mind this portion to be a little larger. My wife took the braised beef noodle soup, which was a much larger course than the Dan Dan noodles, with a very comforting touch. It's a good place but there is definitely room for improvement. However, for the price tag and the category that it belongs to, I would recommend this restaurant.

PmLnFtjV0ScQ_U18P-u1BQ.text: Be prepared to wait a few minutes. This is a small location with limited space. There is also very limited space to wait.   The soup dumplings, jellyfish salad and tofu appetizers were good. Everything else we got was fine. It was fun to watch them hand make the items though the window. Other than to get soup dumplings I don't think I'd return.

J2C9M4_VM-515aJ3LbyjUw.text: TRY THE PORK SOUP DUMPLINGS!!!! SO. GOOD!!   I love everything I've tried on their menu but my favorites are the pork soup dumplings, beef noodle soup and the Dan Dan noodles!  The service is consistent and I really enjoy being able to see them make the different kinds of noodles through the glass!  We often order everyday noodles for delivery and their delivery service always seems to be faster than expected.

OEHcYa7fWyliydbrvqvVJA.text: This restaurant is easily one of my new favorite places in Pittsburgh! I used to live in Squirrel Hill and I can't believe I had not been here until now.   Friends of mine we visiting town so my girlfriend and I took them here. We were seated immediately even though it was busy. We started with some bubble tea and that was wonderful! I got the mango bubble tea (that's what I always get when I get bubble tea) and it was the best I had in a while.   I ordered the Pork Soup Dumplings because the woman sitting next to us recommend that as an appetizer. They were the best dumplings I've ever eaten in my life. The flavors in side were so complex and delicious. They melted in my mouth. I have no idea how they got so many flavors into one tiny dumpling. They were so fresh and I could have eaten 20 more!   I ordered the Braised Beef Noodle Soup for dinner. We waited maybe 7 minutes and the food came out. It was steaming hot and fresh. The noodles were cooked to perfection and the broth was great! I couldn't finish all of my food because I was so full.   I will be going back soon for dinner! This is now my go to place to take people from out of town. I commend the staff because of how polite they were and they never missed a beat.   This place is a must visit if you're ever in the city looking for a delicious new food experience.

Ec-agRVI2woA8ZivhmT2Ng.text: This is my go to hand pulled noodle place. Oh wait, there's only one in Pittsburgh! Their beef and tendon noodle is on point. We would also get the steamed soup dumplings to share every time. Their bubble tea is also one of my favorites in Pittsburgh. I love their mango pudding, red bean and grass jelly toppings!

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Braised Beef and Tendon Noodle Soup

B5Fy_m6RIOVGJ3PzLZD8xA.text: I got the oxtail noodle soup with wide noodles, and really enjoyed the food itself, but the waiter took away my food before I was done! Didn't check with me at all or even look at the stunned expression on my face, just swooped in and was already on his way back to the kitchen by the time I said "Excuse me". 5 stars for food, 3 for service.

fIyVDADipunySVlCNjRXcA.text: About what you would expect from a place so named. The house-made noodles and soup dumplings are wonderful and the prices reasonable. Can be busy during lunch and dinner times.    Not recommended for food allergies.

KdM1CLaQGuvl0LnQVmIHAg.text: Some dishes are hit-or-miss, but the XLB (soup dumplings) are the best I've ever had, hand to god. Can't go wrong with the cold sesame noodles.  Beef roll was also scrumptious.  Dan Dan noodles didn't contain one grain of pork, though not advertised as such, I generally get some pork love in my Dan Dan.  Noods arrived quite mushy, hence why I preferred the cold sesame. Potstickers arrive in a way that I had not seen before - cooked as a sheet and with a crisp bottom - fascinating idea, but it prevented us from cleanly separating the dumplings from the rest, so filling got torn out. Veggie dumplings were stuffed with mealy, pureed - turnip, maybe?  Felt like it would definitely be adored by the kiddos, but it ached for some seasoning.

6HgqUG9uNFzwF4z7ovZQ2A.text: Absolutely incredible noodle and dumpling restaurant located in the heart of Squirrel Hill. I don't know why it took me so long to write a review for one of my favorite restaurants in Pittsburgh.  Upon walking in, you'll probably jump a few times from the loud bangs from the chefs hand pulling and preparing the flour noodles. Luckily, you can watch them prepare everything so you know when to expect the loud noodle slaps. They do not take reservations and there is almost always a wait, but it's definitely worth it.  Onto the food, I believe you have 4 types of noodle choices when you order soups or noodle bowls: wide flour, thin flour, wide rice, thin rice. My favorite is definitely the wide flour noodles, they're as wide as fettucine pasta but the chew, springiness, and freshness of these wide flour noodles are incredible. Ordering-wise, the Hot and Spicy Wonton noodles optioned with wide flour noodles (obviously) is my go-to item. Nothing can beat the plump dumplings and the smokey spicy chili oil that blankets your nest of noodles. This is a dish i don't think I will ever get sick of. Also, don't forget the soup dumplings! It should be a crime to walk out of Everyday Noodles without ordering at least one round of soup dumplings with every visit. There's a little bit of a process to eat these, but everyone has their own technique. I prefer to poke a little hole on the side of the soup dumpling and sip the soup out. Then I bite the top of the soup dumpling and add a little drop or two of the soy sauce they give, along with a tiny spoonful of red chili oil, followed by a little bit of the fresh ginger laid on top. The flavors you'll experience in that single bite are unlike anything else. I like to finish off with a Mango Milk bubble tea optioned with the lychee jelly and bubbles, a great way to finish off a fantastic meal.   Everything I've had at Everyday Noodles has been absolutely spectacular, I have my favorites on the menu that are hard to stray from, but I can't wait to go back and try the noodle soups, especially on a cold day.

RLGqZujsPs41V20IYb-e3g.text: Taiwan style fresh noodle in lots of the traditional Chinese flavors, you can see the live noodle making and dumpling steaming actions.  The noodle soup is very salty on both of my orders.  Very salty.  Decor is similar to many of the contemporary ramen shops, work glow is efficient.  If you park at the blue dot parking lot, there is a good chance that you just need an hour to go in and out.

ngjauIsnmGglUlLnMfVcXQ.text: Service is excellent. Stop by to watch the noodles being made in the dining area. The menu is large and they are very accommodating. I was with a small group we ordered the braised beef over rice, hot and spicy wonton noodles, pork and vegetable pot stickers and the soup dumping. Everything was fantastic!! I wouldn't change anything about our order. It was super timely for lunch.   PSA - the hot and spicy wonton noodles are spicy!! Ha

grId0vYdushJo6vLQqAUHQ.text: It was ok. Its very busy and has a pretty decor. The food was ok. My fav part was the cute tea they have. Nothing to memorable otherwise.

FB173VRj6tnnW0QpaufTQA.text: This is one of my absolute favorite restaurants in Pittsburgh.  The restaurant is small, so during peak hours, be prepared to wait for a bit. However, don't let the wait discourage you - it is well worth it.  The aesthetic of the restaurant is almost industrial modern - there's a giant glass window that separates you from the kitchen, where you can watch the chefs make the soup dumplings while you wait for your food (this is seriously cool!)  The food itself is amazing. The pork soup dumplings are fantastic - perfect for sharing as an appetizer. They are definitely a must have. I've also tried the gyoza, which is also extremely good.   Now into the noodles. The noodle soups are some of the best I've ever had. Everything tastes fresh - and you can tell it is by watching the chefs hand pull the noodles from your seat. The broths are extremely rich and flavorful. I recommend getting the thin noodles with the chicken noodle soup - it is simply to die for, especially when it's cold and you want to warm up.  For those who can make it out - this place is a must.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Chicken noodle soup with shredded chicken

QoCCkKzpG14w1RRnXhV9Lw.text: Yesterday I decided to be the porker that I really am. I went and ran at the JCC and then met a friend for dinner. After trying to decide where we were going to go I remembered that this place is my go to, even if I sometimes forget to suggest it. I always remember at the last minute but it is never a bad thing. Honestly, this place is great. The food, the ambiance, the staff. Everyone and everything is just top notch.   We got there around 7PM and the staff greeted us warmly. We were taken to a little table in the back. I should have asked to sit near where they were making the noodles since it was my friends first time being there I would have liked him to be able to watch the noodle magic, but next time for sure.   We were in the back corner area but that did not distract from the experience. The waitress still came around and asked us how we were doing and was always there to answer questions. I had her go down the list of the dry noodles and boy, was she on it. Also, how do they refill your water glass so fast without you noticing it? It is mind blowing, or maybe I am just not that observant.   Now, as I get into how much food we actually consumed, just know, I did start this review by saying my inner porker did come out.   Appetizers: Golden Tofu Nuggets: These were really good. I will say that they are little medallions covered in some nice panko fried to perfection. The plate was full and we were able to enjoy them. The only thing, if they were smaller they would have been easier to consume and the tofu inside would have been fried a bit better. While it was good, I enjoy the littler sizes so that the tofu tastes less like tofu and more like fried goodness. These were good, but the portion size was a little larger.  Pork Soup Dumplings: These are amazing. Nothing is as good as these pork soup dumplings. While a little hard to eat at first they really are delicious. You just have to pop a little hole in the side, get a little of the soy sauce on them and boom. Amazing party in your mouth. The soup broth is flavorful and not at all salty and the little meatball, yummy!  Rolled Onion Pancakes with Sliced Beef: First-time trying, and it will not be the last. It was like a little beef burrito. It was super good. The fried pancake surrounded the beef mixing into the perfect little sized sandwich. This could have been eaten on its own. Seriously. It was filling and good. I will want to try the veggie version of this the next time I go.   Entree: Hot and Spicy Wonton Noodles: Yum. It comes with about four wontons, spicy noodles, and a little bit of broccoli. I think that for the next time I might ask for extra veggies to be added to the dish. The noodles were spicy, they were not lying, but it was not overwhelming. I would say that you can also add meat to the dish but this one did not really need meat since the wonton's were filled. Nummy Nummy in my tummy.   Ok, it was a great night and I cannot say how much fun I had coming here. The food was great and so was the company. I am happy that I got to show someone another noodle experience and they left raving and saying they are taking their friends here. I think that is a win in my book. Come here, you will not be disappointed.

3Es4-NBMSWHoA1dcdKzUkg.text: This is such a fun eating experience. I love to take friends here so they can enjoy watching the chefs make noodles behind the window; it truly is fascinating! And the food is wonderful too! The food is so fresh and the timing is fast!

m3lMzWNMebko56IG-qFGYQ.text: The xiaolongbao (soup dumplings) are decent tasting, moderately priced, but inconsistently shaped. Once, they were served at a temperature that was slightly too cool, and a few times they broke. The amount of soup is not too great either. It's not Din Tai Fung level but nonetheless it seems to be the best that you can get in Pittsburgh.  The beef noodles is okay but nothing too special. It comes with about 6 cubes of beef, two broccoli florets and one thin slice of daikon radish. The beef is tender and flavourful but does not quite reach the melt-in-your-mouth quality of better beef noodle places.  Generally the food is authentic and acceptable, and superior to the other Chinese restaurants in the area.

kBBHvdEeZZH7C7TYc98Xxg.text: When you are in Pittsburgh craving some great Taiwanese food....this is the place!     I was taken here by a family friend who came upon this place because they were missing the home cooked feel.  They didn't steer me wrong.    The restaurant is small but they move fast!  The staff was knowledgeable and very courteous.      I let my friends order and we had more food than we could finish!   The thin noodles with beef were delicious.  We had it both dry and with brother.   Just enough flavor with being overly powerful!   Also ordered the soup dumplings, fried pot stickers, and pork belly slider.  I could probably just eat those all day!     Don't be afraid to try this place out!  It's a must try for anyone!

ozKGDbDnQqaqyJI9joQ5qg.text: Everyday tastiness!  I've been to this country's finest Chinatowns...San Francisco, New York, etc...  And I have to honestly say that I was impressed with the service, decor and food at Everyday Noodles.    Let me first say that the service can often be brutal in a lot Chinese restaurants...noncommittal stares from wait staff, lack of patience when asking about dishes,  etc.. you know the drill.  However, my daughter Muff and I recently went to Everyday Noodles on a busy Saturday and while the line was lengthy, it moved pretty quickly thanks to the drill sergeant hostess up front.  Here's a further breakdown of the rest of the visit:  Decor - Truly appreciated the lack of faux Chinese decor.  Loved the lightness/airiness of the place.  Seating could be placed a little farther apart, but hey, it still beats 99% of the Chinese restaurants around.   Food -  Shrimp, Pork and Vegetable Potstickers - Well done and you could actually taste each component, but nothing overpowered anything else. Yum!  Rolled Onion Pancake w/ Sliced Beef - Never seen this dish here in Pittsburgh, but I have had it elsewhere and this one stacks up pretty well.  Double yum!  Taiwanese Style Pork Belly Slider - Okay, braised pork belly with fragrant soy/ginger/garlic goodness?  Come on, man!  How can you go wrong!  Chinese Happy Family yum!   Dan Dan Noodles Szechuan Style - Wonderful chew to the noodles and we added a little extra stink to it by adding some garlic-chili sauce.  Great!  Overall, a great addition to the Pittsburgh food scene!  A round-the-world chopstick thumbs up!

UftYfRvTSNsahF1td2yP0w.text: This place is awesome and lives up to the reviews! Soup dumplings and braised beef noodle soups are a must!!

Hzd9YSXk9rWhvBPHhfX0-Q.text: Vegetarian friendly.  Be warned that this place fills up fast and some tables are very close to the kitchen.  Rather than sit so close we opted for take out (be warned they don't have phones so you have to in person put in your order).   They are happy to substitute any meat noodle with tofu (just watch out for the type of broth). We loved the Chiang Mai curry noodle with tofu and Mr. Jessica ordered the see yew with shrimp. We order 1/5 spicy to get a bit of spice and flavor but not to be overwhelmed.  Their service was blistering fast on a packed night. We waited less than 10 mins between ordering and walking out the door with our order in hand!

CdxKDyh13weNNm9wvWbquA.text: Recently, a near-monsoon and the flooding that resulted from it had threatened to strand Kay and I in the East End one evening upon quitting time, giving us a perfect excuse to wait out the storms by sampling one of the shooting stars in Pittsburgh's culinary scene: Everyday Noodles.   Shimmering interiors, a lovely hostess, communal seating arrangements, and ringside-seat kitchen action immediately lifted the gloom from our weary, weeknight shoulders.   Our laid-back, long-locked server, one who reminded us of a musician friend of ours in appearance and comportment, took our orders via a pencil-and-paper order form system much like Burgatory does. Once our choices were circled and confirmed, the circus of taste, smell, and sight began.   Having researched the menu days before after a featured Yelp review arrested my interest, I knew I had to begin with something quite alien, new, and therefore immensely intriguing to me: The Taiwanese Pork Belly Slider.   The gelatinous bun that contained the uncannily unctuous, meaty, and flavorsome pork was quite simply not of this earth. Possessing the texture of marshmallow, a meringue, raw dough, and a hamburger roll all at once, it seemingly absorbed the taste of the hog in the same way a tofu would. The possibilities of what to place inside this futuristic bread are infinite. Chipped ham? Mozzarella? Mortadella? Nutella? Whaddya say, fella?  Next in line was an octet of something I've only seen Bourdain relish reverentially on television: Soup Dumplings of the pork and crab variety.   While not as large as those I've seen in the media, the pouches of painstakingly housemade dough that arrived to our table in a steam basket had me convulsing rhapsodically as Long Tall Tony has done whenever eating something favorable for your entertainment (envy? vicarious pleasures?). Eschewing the traditional method of biting a piece from the top and vampirically slurping the internal fluids out of each defenseless, quivering packet, I merely allowed them to cool, lifted them towards my mouth with the spoon provided, and consumed them with one bite, the broth flooding my palate with warm ambrosia as my teeth lacerated the exterior, the meats barely requiring manducation.  Served at precisely the same time was my Oxtail Noodle Soup Consomme, complete with an ornate, occult-looking wooden ladle. My father has long sworn never to eat oxtail again in his days for reasons that remain unclear. For that reason, oxtail has been one of those animal parts that has always held a forbidden mystique to me. Just what does it taste like? Why does dad revile it?  As every stock-soaked beef morsel fell from their shamrock-shaped bones and withered into sweet nothingness onto my tongue, I thought amiably only of one thing: Corned Beef. Oh what a Beef on Weck or French Dip one could make with oxtail. In this context, however, I had to settle for having my oxtail chased down with a sea of dark and darkly savory Oriental bouillon in which tender, lovingly scratch-prepared noodles bobbed and drifted.  Dessert was a doublet of delight. The Crispy Creamy Mini Buns were just that. Ideal in their glazed glory, they immediately brought to mind donuts, particularly those from a wildly popular chain that expanded too quickly for its own good. The Sweet Egg Yolk Steamed Buns, though, were where horizons were expanded. Built from the same, surreal substance as the buns involved in the aforementioned pork belly sliders, the three orbs with canary irises were filled with a neon yellow custard that was an exercise in saline vs. saccharine alchemy. One bite had me dreaming of eggs on Sunday morning. Another would take me to dessert that same evening.   Everyday Noodles is somewhat of a misnomer in that this isn't "everyday" Chinese. Rather, what's being served up here is exactly the manner of Chinese cuisine I'd been craving for all too many moons; the dishes I'd never heard of before and never knew existed. While I'll continue to enjoy General Tso's Chicken and Crab Rangoon as much as my fellow countrymen, Everyday Noodles has certainly broadened the local landscape of Asian fare by simply elevating and introducing to Pittsburgh palates those (well-executed) dishes that were formerly obscure to us. For that I thank its staff and ownership.   P.S. Speaking of ownership, the restaurant's co-founder Mike Chen came to our table to chat briefly with us as we dined. Until he told me, I had no idea that Mr. Chen also owns Tamari. Ironically, while EN's pork belly was superb, Tamari's wasn't quite as good (read: dry. look up my review. it was one of only two gaffes).   P.P.S. All of our dishes were affordable, easily shareable, and conducive to varying levels of hunger. Be it a quick bite or a grand feast you're searching for, EN has a meal for you.   P.P.P.S. The service and atmosphere were both stellar all around. Break out of the box of Americanized Chinese food and make time for Everyday Noodles.

b734ggJPAYSBWWXpLDbW4A.text: On this Saturday I went to dine at Everyday Noodles, not for the noodles but for DIM SUM!!! Oh the yummy bunny and dumpling goodness. We ordered big , every inch of surface space on our table was covered with food. We had everything from green tea, to beef and green onion pancakes and sweet egg yolk steam bun and it was all very very very tasty.  Squirrel Hill for me is a neighborhood seldom visited but when I do make the 40 minute bus trek I always find a hidden gem or new development.   My two gripes and I will try to keep them  short, my boyfriend's Taiwanese style pork belly slider and our beef and green onion pancakes were COLD burrr, chilly not warm at all and the waiter was a tad to brisk with his intro , snatching the menu away from us before we were fully done examining it.   I am fully settled into the Fall semester and have gained a foot hold in my school work and have struck the sweet spot between balancing school work and my job(s) with that being said it is time to get my YELP on again.

tYxO-r6FBe8Hk_set5Vl5A.text: The latest inspection from the Allegheny County Health Department (ACHD) turned up some food safety problems. The inspection in April 2015 turned up violations in several areas: Cross-contamination prevention Cleaning and sanitization Handwashing facilities Pest management Toxic items Contamination Prevention - Food, Utensils and Equipment Walls & ceilings Read the inspection reports on Everyday Noodles at webapps.achd.net/Restaur...

X-kkWYREj4GaRHgTuIFLLg.text: I love the pork soup dumplings here, and the watercress or broccoli is also a big favorite. Be prepared to wait--everyone loves this place. The only reason I don't go more is that while I want to like the noodle dishes, there's not one that's "perfect" for me. In general, too much noodle, and not enough meat/veggies in those. My favorite is the wonton one, and it's so spicy that I can't usually eat the whole thing (and I am a hot sauce fan, so I usually persevere in such situations). The decor is very cute and I love watching them make noodles and dumplings. I like to go in spring/fall because it's often overly warm in winter and I can't do hot soupy things in summer.

pbnvYu8RXbkzmSNVSphpuw.text: I came here with a couple friends, but we left early due to limited food options.   The restaurant is very nice and cozy inside. The staff is attentive, and the jasmine tea was very good. However, everything that looked appealing had pork in it... That's  well and dandy for people that eat pork, but not so good for those that don't. Usually there are choices of meats, but the foods were pre made and the pork could not be extracted. I will probably be back for the jasmine tea and the vegetable dumplings though.

20yGAwm5ZCBkTq3BcxlNrg.text: Amazing place, Very Friendly, Great service, would take my friends and family back here soon! Love it!!

cNtgPvwQPL1kUvfwISmp0A.text: It was my first time with the boyfriend last night and we both loved it. Was so crowded when we came and thought we gonna have to wait awhile but nope, about few mins later they seated us right away!   Literally ordered 8 different dishes (no lie!) and finished most of them and just took home some of the leftover shumai. Our server was such a nice guy and he even asked us twice if we're sure about those 8 dishes because thats a lot of food    I enjoyed my time there -- the atmosphere is nice and different. If you're from like CA or something like that dont compare too much. For us here in the burgh its a different style yet reasonable dimsum place. Def gonna come back soon!

QmnWlXeOt5PS812-hOdU2w.text: This place hit the spot. All the food was fresh, delicious, came in generous portions and the service was fast and great. We called ahead for a large party and they held our table which was very nice. By the time we left, there was a line out the door - well deserved. The xiao long bao were delicious but my favorite was the Shrimp, Pork and Vegetable Wontons with Mung Bean Noodles, Schezuan Style. The sweet egg yolk steamed bun was also delicious.

R_fENhtv9ZkQOmXtSvRNLw.text: When I came back to the burgh, many of my friends said good things about this new noodle shop in town. I kept hearing things like cheap, authentic, flavorful, and amazing bubble tea. Well, let met just say that the bubble tea is most definitely the best in the city! Delicious, customizable, and a good value for the size. I loved their taro tea even though I'm usually not a fan.   One person disagreed about the food, though, and I didn't believe her so I dragged her here to show her that she must've just caught them on a bad day. Afterwards I have to agree with her opinion that this place was a bit underwhelming. The concept is great - casual, simple and authentic Chinese food done well/small menu, gallery to see fresh noodles being cooked by experts from Asia. And hand drawn noodles! What's not to love? Unfortunately the execution fell short.   Beef noodle soup - If they are trying for the Taiwanese beef noodle soup, they completely missed the mark on the spicy, acidic, tomatoy, intense broth. If that's what you expect, you will be utterly disappointed. But as it stands on its own, the flavor could still be more developed. I did love that they gave generous portions of beef (flavorful and tender) and noodles. But the texture of the noodles was rigid and not chewy at all :( Disappointing. I love hand drawn noodles, but I guess I'd have to keep going to Philly to get my fix :( and at 1/2 the price, too.   Pork over rice - Pretty good. This one is definitely a Taiwanese staple, but tastes a bit different than several of the variations I've tried before. They use much leaner meat which would be ggood for the self conscious but sacrifices a bit in the flavor department. One spice was overpowering, but I didn't try enough of my friend's to remember what it is. Overall, much better than the noodle soup.  Seaweed - Best dish we had. Great texture, well dressed, and super refreshing. A decent portioned appetizer for $6  Spicy szechuan noodles - worst  dish we had. Expensive, completely underseasoned sauce and underwhelming wontons. We had to ask for salt because it was just inedible. They now come with mung bean noodles.  Overall, I was a bit disappointed. I wouldn't be against coming here at others' suggestion, but it's nothing worth mentioning :/

WT1gYJrvNRiX_HEaT8NFfA.text: I traveled to China a few years ago and discovered soup dumplings.  It was difficult finding good American food while there, so the dumpling find was a life saver.  Anyway, I was searching for something in Pittsburgh and found Everyday Noodles.  The kids and I showed up about 15 minutes after they opened and the wait was already 25 minutes.  Once seated we ordered some fried potstickers. They looked a little strange but tasted excellent.  Next was the soup dumplings. We ordered a variety to sample. I would say they were just ok.  I guess a dumpling can only be so good, but compared to the real deal in China, they were just ok.  We finished with an order of red bean paste for dessert.  That was good. Not real sweet, like sugar, but good.

VtRuk4xhReEylKVGWzjTyg.text: I'm almost hesitant to recommend this place as it's already super busy and I would love to keep it a secret but wow is this place good.  I've been there 4times now and have preserved the same meal.  Pork soup dumplings , pickled cucumber , spicy won ton noodles and sweet egg custard buns.  I have dreams about it. ...

9DonybaTF0xBQAHu3NmP9g.text: Wasn't super impressed with the Dan Dan noodles. The noodles themselves were ok, but the modest portion of bland shredded chicken on top kind of ruined the dish.

r9Yd5H4awFo7t4AdHdnWiw.text: Being in Pittsburgh, it's hard to find good authentic noodles and Asian food. The food is delicious and are basic where the description in the menu is easily understandable. It really hits the spot when you're craving some noodle soup. The price is decent/reasonable for the demand.   The space is a little tight because they utilize as much of the space of possible. I love being able to see fresh noodles being made through a glass separation. This restaurant does get busy so the wait can be long. And because the wait usually is long, when you're finally seated it feels as if the staff is constantly rushing you.

zCYSHo22pRDLx1zBa9hpSQ.text: Like a lot of people said, the place can get pretty crowded, but the food here is really great and at a great price! Not only are the noodles fantastic, the soup dumplings here are phenomenal. Delivery services are also very quick!   If it's your first time here, I would highly recommend the soup dumplings. If you like spicy food, I would recommend the dan dan noodles and the hot spicy wonton noodles. The pork & vegetable potstickers are pretty good, except they are a bit greasy so keep that in mind. If you are in the mood for some noodle soup, I would recommend the braised beef (and tendon) noodle soup. While it is a bit more expensive than the dry noodles (like the dan dan noodles and the hot spicy wonton noodles), there are quite a lot of beef pieces, so it is definitely worth it.

OCH-_q27PLj7sbqvSOmr0g.text: A place that makes their own noodles and dumplings?!?!?!  YES, PLEASE.  I got the beef + tendons noodles and an order of soup dumplings.  DID NOT DISAPPOINT.  They also premix the vinegar and soy sauce for you, so the sauce is the perfect ratio every time.  Also decided to get the milk tea from here, even though I'm usually strongly against bubble tea from restaurants because it's usually horrible.  This place proved me wrong.  So, so wrong.  I think the milk tea was the creamiest/thickest milk tea I've had + the balls were perfection.  The best milk tea I had during my Pittsburgh trip.  You can also sit in front of the window where they make the dumplings and noodles.  Best.view.ever.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Menu
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Soup dumplings + beef tendon noodles.  That view!!

2wjg_-O3_CV_j1HOZ__L8Q.text: If you are craving for good dumplings, this is the place to go to! My cold noodles very pretty authentic and I enjoyed it, but much husband found his soup to have pretty raw meat. Which he did not particularly enjoy.

H0UGemRy4AswUtJOPlFuNA.text: I came to this place for lunch when I was visiting my brother. I was surprised that he decided to take me to an Asian restaurant in Pittsburgh, but it was pretty good! I liked watching them pull the noodles in house, and the XLB was a bit salty but still enjoyable.   I did not love the sauce in my dan dan noodles, but my brother's beef noodle soup was very satisfying.   I don't know if I would come back, but I enjoyed my visit.

FrOugYUpNh2zQMGulG_qVQ.text: What a fun place. There is a glass window between where you sit and the folks making the food, so we could see them making the dumplings and slamming thus huge piece of dough down on the counter  (and obviously hear them too!). There were many different options on the menu--noodle bowls (I got the beef brisket one which was delicious), apps (we got dumplings) as well as I believe rice bowls and a few more other options.  You fill out your food order on the form at the table. They take the form and deliver your food to you. The tables are all in a row where the wall side is one continuous long bench and the opposite side of the tables have chairs.   It was a fresh, light, quick and delicious lunch in an entertaining and energetic environment experience.

hEAYkF3E2zOi65sXfH7abg.text: The food is decent here. But the portions are not the biggest. You have to order multiple things in order to be fall a little bit. Their soup dumpling is amazing but it's pricey. I like the fact that you can watch them cook everything in front of you.  It is pretty authentic with the taste

Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

l8pcxkVv5rP_Qpb6ZMJrYA.text: first visit here. staff was pleasant and thoroughly explained menu options to our group. food was prepared quickly and was delicious. comfortable atmosphere, cute decor!

6kczk-n9LCMYTBGKTgkw3g.text: I don't know much about the different types of noodles/dumplings, but everything I try here is fantastic. I feel comfortable ordering something I've never heard of because because I'm confident I'll like it. The soup dumplings are so good, I could live off them.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

vxDkIC9XWof687ZwcSmvjw.text: Everyday Noodles is so delicious! Even if you're a bit of a noob when it comes to non-Americanized Chinese food like me, don't be too intimidated to try this place! The staff is all friendly and ready to answer any questions you may have. We were seated at the bench right in front of the noodle window and watching them hand make the noodles and dim sum was amazing. We ordered the dan Dan noodles (pretty spicy), the pork belly over rice, and the pork pot stickers. It was all packed with flavor and super filling. It also came out super duper fast! Mmm I'm craving it again just thinking about it. Their noodle soups are all amazing too! We had to wait quite a while for a table, but it was totally worth it. BYOB with a corking fee too. Go check it out!!

ObldIzQ2002fAJajTo9e1A.text: This is the only place to get fresh xiaolong baos in Pittsburgh. It's not bad, considering Pittsburgh's quality of Chinese food. The food is worth the wait if you're craving XLB and Chinese chicken soup, albeit the tight spaces you have to work with during the winter months. My friends enjoy the dandan noodles, but we mainly come for the dumplings. Their boba milk tea isn't bad either! I wish they offered Jasmine green milk tea instead of matcha, but it's not that big of a deal.

cCZ2CJf5w-So54BA8tTT1w.text: I thought I would try a little of everything since it was my first time I order the pork belly slider, beef noodle soup, and pork and crab soup dumplings.  Wowwwww! Everything was fantastic. Pork belly slider was moist and very flavorful, not dry by any stretch of the imagination. The beef noodle soup was bursting with flavor and fall apart beef. The soup dumplings....yes please!   Overall amazing topped with a very friendly and attentive staff. They make sure you are well taken care of and leave full. Plan to wait a little bit during the busy times but well worth every minute and penny!

Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Beef noodle soup
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pork belly slider.....yes please

jTBBteHbBvQL-au4EBNAOw.text: I actually came with the intention to update a review- only to find I have never posted one. Seriously?? But that's ok, I will write my review by telling a story that recently took place this weekend.   I was driving along Forbes Ave with my boyfriend and sent a snap video to one of my friends who had just moved from Pittsburgh to Jersey City. The video was pretty choppy, as my boyfriend was driving and I was zooming in the wrong places on the street; so while I was recording, I said in the video, "Brent, can you recognize what I'm trying to send you?!"  And the following image is a screenshot of the message he sent back, which is a perfect representation (and review) of Everyday Noodles.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

RL2pI92GI8R8QRzig6zzhA.text: This restaurant was a huge hit with our family gathering. Cautions first: this place is very small and VERY busy. Despite calling ahead for a table, we still waited 20+ minutes in a crush of people. So plan ahead.   That said, once we were seated, we loved everything. Food came out very quickly and every dish was delicious. Pork soup dumplings were probably the favorite, but wonton noodle soup was a close second. Our meals also included potstickers, scallion pancakes, Dan Dan noodles, baby bok choy and even jellyfish salad! Every dish brought oohs and aahs and happy diners. We can't wait to go back.

3MsOA_93slVC-SMdYZ9XFw.text: Amazing food every time I've come here. Love the pork soup dumplings, minced pork noodles, pickled mustard noodle soup, egg custard buns, and the mini crispy buns. I tried the drunken chicken once and it wasn't for me, but I don't think I was just familiar with the flavor and texture.

qAqTG9W9RFveWZkDl5spSA.text: Soup dumplings are out of this world! Anytime we are in Pittsburgh we stop here. It's busy but worth the wait.

iH7URDgxm6952I27SobQuQ.text: Wow!  Our absolute favorite restaurant in Pittsburgh.  We get the same order every time - pork soup dumplings, broccoli, pan fried pork buns, noodles with minced pork sauce!  It's a decent drive for us but well worth it!  There's normally a wait, no more than 15-20 minutes. BYOB too! Amazing!

0d5li4YgkyeQt6galT0nAQ.text: I dont believe they hire or hired any chief from Taiwan. As a business owner I understands a bit on how this industrial goes. It will be too costly to do so, or they are est chain restaurant. I dont discriminate their way of advertising, as long as they are making good food. I seen white make Vietnamese, black making Thai, chinese making chinese, and chinese making it All. so as that being said, I respects Everyday Noodle's business and appreciate people making good food.

dSyrDEKJuT0_GtNHSCKhDQ.text: Everyday Noodles has a stellar menu of noodle goodness. They make their flour noodles in the restaurant which is a great authentic touch. The pork soup dumplings are out of this world and I highly recommend them. Little dough pouches filled with savory broth and pork. It's best eating them with the provided spoon. Poke a little hole in the dumpling to allow some broth to spill into the spoon and slurp it up! I ordered the beef noodle soup and it was a HUGE portion! Tender chunks of beef, a deep and flavorful broth, a chunk of bok choy and plenty of noodles. I had plenty leftover for lunch the next day. I also tried the Dan Da noodles which were spicy and peanuty and an equally large serving size. The cold sesame noodles were refreshing, light and also had a peanuty flavor. They also made for easy leftover since they didn't require any reheating. If you love noodles, you'll LOVE Everyday Noodles!

Ax9EkrDZfTwHfnfXjMd4hA.text: I went with my husband (CM student ) for the first time today, I really liked, the hubby just "liked". We ordered the braised beef over rice and the steamed vegetable dumplings. The dumplings were very good - especially with chili paste (you'll have to ask for this on the side). The braised beef dish was also very good - the texture of the meat was perfect, the flavors - complex. There is one major flaw with the meat dish and that is that there was a substantial amount of fat. About one-fourth of the beef was  fat. Seemed wasteful as we didn't eat it and I wasn't too happy about the owner's cutting corners that way. But - I did really enjoy my meal at Everyday Noodles, and if you order veggie - there's no going wrong.

sHdWulDBX10ufDDOLfvmvw.text: The restaurant only opened on Wednesday and I am ready to add this to my list of favorites. There were 3 of us and we had oxtail soup, pork noodles, Dan Dan noodles, eggplant, bok choy, veggie dumplings, beef and scallion roll and bubble tea. I don't even know how to pick a favorite! The place is cute as can be and it's as much fun to watch them make the food as it is to eat it. The place is busy now so there was a wait to be seated but the food was served very quickly once seated and the service was good. On a street with so many good restaurants this place will do very well.

maB5-N8ckZFjZBRqlxEYnA.text: The good here is fine. The manager is not. Last night my family went there. We were a party of nine. We had appetizers and many entrees. We spent a ton of money and left a hefty tip. After we finished our entrees, the manager came to our table and told us that we needed to leave so that she could use our table for other waiting customers. He thing is, it was a cold night in Pittsburgh and there were no other large parties waiting and there were several other tables available in the restaurant. We were so shocked that we were told to leave that we quickly got our things together and proceeded to head to the door. On the way out I told the manager that I have never, ever been told to leave a restaurant to make space for another customer who was waiting, and that I thought that this was extremely rude. I will never go back there because of the manager's behavior. Restaurant patrons should not be treated this way.  Go to another noodle restaurant. This one isn't worth it.

rRrIct-d8mH-n3zyjETThA.text: I had high hopes for this place but it was all really disastrous. The service is not that bad, but the food is just awful(sorry guys) some just don't seem right and this was one of those places, could not enjoy ourselves. Will not be going back.

2O7Zui4cKS_8BRb8DgNtHg.text: Went here in a party of 3. We ate very well for ~$25 a head.  Pros -Fantastic soup dumplings! -Great potsticker. -Friendly staff. -Good atmosphere.  Cons -Freshly made bubble tea took a while

O3jcLcIVb-fa3yzfDX9j6A.text: This is a nice restaurant in terms of Taiwanese standard. I have come to this restaurant three times. In the first two times (in early March), I found their supposedly best seller, soup dumplings, very disappointing.   The third time I came I decided to give soup dumplings another chance. Surprisingly, this time was totally different! I saw the owner and told him that the soup dumplings got a big improvement. He told me that many customers have complained to him that the soup dumplings were disappointing. Therefore, he decided to hire the master of the previous young chef who was in charge of making soup dumplings. And it turned out to be a right decision.  For me, the basic required features of soup dumplings are two: 1) the dumplings must have a good amount of soup inside; 2) the soup has to be very, very hot. There are of course other important criteria for judging the tastiness of soup dumplings. Believe or not, the soup dumplings that I ate in the first two times never passed the low par of the basic criteria. They totally looked like a joke. But now they seem getting better.   The reviews saying that their food is too bland is partly True but also a bit unfair. When people ask me what is the difference between Chinese food and Taiwanese food, one thing that I usually say is that Taiwanese food tastes not too heavy because of the influence from Japan. Most Taiwanese do not add soybean sauce in a bowl of steamed rice like some Americans would do. Most Taiwanese do no add too much hot sauce in the noodle soup like some Chinese would do. So, if you ONLY accept heavy taste food, this is not a place that will please you. But again, I think that their food is pretty authentic Taiwanese food.  My top five favorite dishes are: 1) soup dumplings; 2) rolled onion pancakes w. sliced beef, 3) pan fried green onion pancake; 4) (thin) noodles with minced pork sauce; and 5) braised pork belly over rice.

imIzhRBjffHDzT9RjrvU1A.text: One of my favorite places in Pittsburgh! The noodles come out quickly and are so so delicious. Their portions are huge, but the noodles warm up nicely in the microwave if you end up taking leftovers home.

FVzhzS3FT7ccbCzZPJRuAA.text: I dream about the pork and crab soup dumplings and minced pork boy choy. Taiwanese pork belly slider is decent. Can't make a bad choice on the menu. Save room for the crispy creamy mini buns.

Ayyup5EJUxfZSf4ac2PXNg.text: Great service, delicious noodles, and a fun atmosphere. The servers were very attentive and personable, and watching the cooks make the noodles was fun.

Nz41pZBJFZSpdfejO_nwqg.text: thought the dim sum part of the menu could've been better but I guess not :( my favorite had to be the egg custard buns and the soup dumpling! the pork bun has too much going on and noodles weren't that great, I wouldn't recommend getting it. our waiter was amazing though, very attentive and made sure we got everything we needed!

4qwEv8bIrU1CYMYcIXhFhg.text: So so good.  You might think, "seriously, another Asian restaurant on Forbes?"   But after the disappointment that is Ramen Bar, Everyday Noodles is just what was missing.  Comforting and tasty noodle soups, dry noodles and most specially, SOUP DUMPLINGS.  I haven't had soup dumplings in Pittsburgh, ever.  I'm pretty sure they don't exist anywhere but at Everday.  And they are perfect.  Perfect thickness in the noodle wrapper, delicious pork & crab meatball with just right amount of broth all in an about 2 inch bundle of soup dumpling perfection.  The pickled mustard greens and pork soup was nice, but I think needed a little more flavor, although there were sauces to pour, so I'll try that next time.  The pickled cucumbers and braised tofu smothered in tantalizing orange sauce were each perfect little beats to get our appetites going.  We  went on opening day, and the service was great, it was crazy busy but the wait time was efficiently managed by an incredibly peppy staff, who all seemed to also be helping each other out with refilling waters and checking on tables. Annnnnd, it's BYOB, and we all know how much I love that.

1zl5xWoreDuLCiDU1yBZBQ.text: This brand new addition to the Sq Hill Asian eat scene looks great on the outside and inside too.  Clean bright and open California style kitchen where you can watch and hear the staff twist and smack the hell out of noodles.  I loved several dishes including a noodle dish with fresh minced pork and the pork slider on a long steamed bun but the dumplings where just OK and the ox tail soup and hot and sour soup was ho hum.  I do recommend this place but am not as in love as I wish I was.  Warning the eggplant though not bad was a surprise as it is served cold.  The place is clean which gets it points but with all the hoopla and the sight of fresh noodles being made and steaming baskets of dumplings I expected more.  I did like the Jasmine tea and the Sweet Bean Paste rolls for a finish.  Enjoy. FYI it is the first of a chain concept that is operating all over Taiwan, Japan, Hong Kong and Australia.  We are lucky to have the first Everyday Noodle in the West open right here in Pittsburgh.  This is a venture by the owner of China Palace.

va-1fI8LNYZqJupWEW_hLw.text: friends hyped up the place. was pretty happy with my first visit but that was it. the noodles with braised beef is the best noodle dish I've tried on their menu and I prefer the thin round noodles over the flat/wide. the manager/owner is super friendly and cool

UvtpBTSxV324HNDXEkPPjQ.text: Excellent!! I love the hand-pull noodles and steam dumplings... people there were nice and considerate......highly recommend!

HMYq5uLQgC59NKHijmH8AA.text: Great restaurant!  The staff give this place their extra star, because in the dozen times we've been there, we've always been served promptly, efficiently, and professionally.  The decor is modern and clean, and the food is light and clean.  It is a nice change to sample asian cuisine that is fresh, and not greasy. The broths are light but flavorful.  We weren't crazy about the deserts, but everything else has been a hit!

-lj9E1r2gOd8R1YRpzO7oQ.text: Soup dumplings and green onion pancake are amazing!

RaTVirCrHwS4x29HE2cxmA.text: There is nothing quite like the pork soup dumplings. They are fantastic! My husband orders a batch alone for his meal. The hot and spicy wonton noodles are not for the heat weak minded. I love spicy food, and this satisfies every craving!

QFMXnqYRd0FjSoKXpXIx1Q.text: OMG!!! This place is fantastic! We had the pickled cucumber, soup dumplings and pan fried pork dumplings.  They were all awesome! Can't wait to go back and explore more of the menu!

iPzI8ojA8duorQp-UvhF4A.text: Timing is key in order to enjoy your experience at this place, I cannot stress this enough. During very busy hours, not only will there be a wait to sit down, but also servers will not be able to reach you or help you out.   The reason I am docking a star is due to the lack of options without pork. All soup broths contain pork as well. Substitutions are unfortunately extremely limited, however, this is due to the fact that they want to keep service as quick as possible.   And by quick, I really mean quick! Food arrives within 10 minutes in waves. Typically your noodle dishes will come out first, following that would be dumplings, then any appetizers or sides, and finally, dessert.  As for price, I would definitely say there are two routes that can happen in visiting here. You can either fill up on a noodle soup for $12, or spend $30+ on small dishes. In other words, this restaurant is as expensive as you make it to be.   Service was good on the times that we came in on non crowded occasions, however, when crowded, it was a bit intimidating.   So far we have gotten:  -crispy tofu nuggets- crispy outside with pudding-like inside, oyster sauce brings out the contrast, get it for sure -vegetable dumplings- not the best Ive had, but still worth trying! Tastes like common gyoza, but has larger amount of filling and a hint of fresh ginger.  -dan dan noodles -hot spicy wonton noodles without wontons- noodles are very good quality, spice tastes a bit flat, but is still bold and hearty -scallion pancake- these are pretty small, but have a crispy outside and pillow inside.  -sesame red bean pancake- crispy, served hot and definitely unique. Would highly recommend! -sesame balls- very well made, on the smaller scale but very inexpensive and delightful. Would highly recommend -steamed egg yolk buns- a bit too dry and could use more filling, but is doughy in texture and has a sugar cookie taste to the filling, which is solid.  -crispy creamy mini buns- kind of like doughnut holes, nothing too special

djf3hp4TbTt4akqqj_oR9A.text: Freshly made noodles and soup dumplings - all are so so good.   My favorites are the beef noodle soup, oxtail noodle soup, and dan dan noodles. We usually get some with wide noodles, some with thin noodles.   The soup dumplings are great too - my favorite is the shrimp and pork. I haven't made it out on a Sunday yet to try the sponge gourd/loofah and shrimp (only available Sundays), which is my favorite at Din Tai Fung.   Pork Belly Slider (gua bao) is good too - it's huge, so you can share it.   Bubble tea is good - they have a more fragrant milk tea here.   Busy busy busy! But if you're willing to share a table, you can get one faster.

F5xaNtrPLmxrrskM6cjsjg.text: Seriously? Jellyfish dish no jellyfish, there is only cabbage and carrot. Noodles tastes not that good as before.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

d9WuA7u3QNq7NaSJgBMtEg.text: Try the pork soup dumplings!!!  I went to this place for the first time about two months ago and have already been back 3 times.  I took my mom here when she came to visit and she was so pleased watching the noodles being made.  Those dumplings are very good.  The pot stickers are my second favorite - they just look so freshly made and they taste great.  I've tried a lot of other things on the menu and not been disappointed.  The servers have always been nice about explaining the different choices.  Over all just a fun place to eat a good meal for a good price!

aYHRlsJsRf_tL9kbK_eNmw.text: Pretty good! I lived in China for three years so I am always looking for some delicious Chinese in the area. I ordered the oxtail noodle soup and it tasted pretty good. Nothing too special, but a solid choice.  I love eating jellyfish salad, so I was excited to see it on the menu! It was very average. Texture was amazing though. Gotta love that crunch.  Safe bet if you are looking for some tasty Chinese. There are more authentic places in the area though!

Wa9Sy1cD_bQMOZHrwxC6Cg.text: I love this place. I eat there once a month at least. They're always nice, efficient and the food is so good!

MBjv8PDqv48XfyxtCly_oQ.text: Came here for lunch looking for a non-meat option. There were only a couple vegetarian dishes, but went with the vegetable dumplings and they were an 8/10. Would be great if they had a vegetarian soup dumpling option...but hopefully they will see this review!

vDX0OZ6KLJLL47wTc1MQ0A.text: Awesome noodle soups. Easy to share or have leftovers. The dim sum is a nice variety. Had the scallion pancakes. Very tasty.  You must try the soup dumplings. Wow! These are little pockets of heaven. I can't wait to go here on the coldest day to slurp up a few those little devils.

9pRQ1m_tnCXl8uJ1XyDlxw.text: They have interesting setting where you can see the chefs through the window making the dumplings/buns/noodles. They have great bubble tea, best in town I would say. The beef noodle soup is more like noodle beef soup--they give you more beef than noodles...the noodle soup is kind of sweet, not for me... The Taiwanese Gua Bun is pretty good, but a little pricy.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Taiwanese Gua Bun, Beef Noodle Soup, Soup Dumplings

W-iFSxfCr9Dz8wNlMkvNfQ.text: I LOVE this place. We've only had the chance to go a few times, but I always leave feeling so satisfied. The prices are right, and the food is the ultimate comfort. I had the beef and tendon soup last time I was there, and it was so rich and luxurious. The handmade noodles can't be beat. All of that chewy, umami goodness...After half of that bowl of soup, I just wanted to curl up under a warm blanket and take a nap! And you absolutely have to try the pork soup dumplings and the vegetable dumplings!  I go back to Everyday Noodles every chance that I get! I wish I was up that way more often.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. My next-day leftovers of the beef &amp; tendon soup. Every bit as good as it was fresh! Words can&#39;t describe this comfort in a bowl.
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Vegetable, shrimp, and pork wontons. Spicy and delicious!
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Vegetable steamed dumplings. Very tasty!

b8_vYps5aebwsU6c7DdqzA.text: I've only gotten take out from here, but I always get the pork belly over rice. It is fantastic and there's plenty to of pork belly to rice ratio and the egg is a nice addition to mix in. The soup dumplings are the real star in this restaurant. They are hot and savory and I love them. The pork bun is more like a large dumpling though, I thought it's be more like a traditional pork bun, but it was still delicious. I still need to try the noodles, so I will be back!

EP5TQDrqGVvlJMpeYoVhcg.text: Recommend beef noodles,tofu and coconut dessert. A must try place for any noodles lover

4Lo63BW-WtSsQyKQpvMcGw.text: This restaurant is TOP.  The noodle and dumplings are made in the restaurant.  The making of the noodles is a bit loud, but hey that's the fun of fresh food.  I've had their spicy noodles, soup dumplings and potstickers.  Everything has been amazing.  I love their spicy oil.  I crave this food.  It's the best.  The broth in their soups are lacking flavor, but I don't go there for the soup, so it doesn't' bother me.  Great job guys!!

eA5SIvdEVxrLFdabfhSUvA.text: Good taste Chinese food . Steamed dumplings are great. Don't forget to try bubble tea!

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Beef noodles

Z8JdJzx2WNqpGni7PDtBkg.text: By faaaaarr and away the only place you want to go for dumplings and noodles!  Everything is prepared in house right in front of you!  The soup dumplings are nirvana. If there is one delicacy you have to endulge in when you are in the east side of pgh.... That is it!!!!! MMMMMMMMMMM DDELISHHHH!!!

oI2Wn5kwtLM7BiFGTFxUSw.text: Steamed soup dumplings, ground pork broccoli, green onion pancake, and dan dan noodles.  Very authentic and good.  Another great option in squirrel hill.  Highly recommend.

O__y8pGmdjhHynHybsWCcA.text: The dumplings are outstanding, but the noodles underwhelmed. They were a little too much like long, thin spatzle. Those dumplings, though. Dang. We had the veggie dumplings and the shrimp/chicken/whatever dumplings. Like, woa.   Also, the bubble tea was pretty top notch. The boba were just a *tad* overdone and gummy, but the tea itself was delicious. It was well above-average.   Minus one star for slow service and greeting during a slow period.

u7T9AdfQ5q3A0Nr3JFpCkg.text: First and foremost, no one mentioned previously that this place is super loud. It's small and has one of those modern restaurant feels, so the acoustics are horrific. Plus, there is the added benefit of hearing the noodle makers bang the large ropes of dough onto the counter repeatedly while you're trying to have a conversation in an otherwise extremely echo-y place. Seriously...I can't believe no on mentioned this.   Be prepared to get RILL cozy with your neighbors. Actually, you may as well just call them table mates, given how close in proximity we were sitting.   I'm also not a big fan of being able to see into the kitchen and know exactly how they're handling my food. Luckily my back was to the whole open glassed-in open kitchen thing, but if you're into watching people make your food, then this is a great spot.   Okay, rant over.   Onto the positives:  Extremely pleasant hostess and waitress. They were very very very helpful answering all of my questions, and very patient with me when I took forever to decide.   The milk bubble tea stuff I had was good. I believe I had the mango milk tea, and it was sweet without being too overbearing. I'm not a ginormous bubble tea fan, but this one was certainly better than others I've had.   I heart dumplings, and the soup ones here were divine. So good, so yum-tastic, and enough to share. My only qualm is that the table we were at was so ridiculously small for how big the container of dumplings was, but as soon as I tried them I quickly stopped giving a damn about lack of table space.   I also tried the pork belly slider and it was OVERLFLOWING WITH DELICIOUS MEATY PORK BELLY NOMS. Between this and the dumplings I was pretty full, but I was also hell bent on trying their noodles.   I hurriedly made a stupid decision and got some sort of vinegar based noodle dish. It was prepared well, but I hated it because I hate the strong taste of vinegar w/ peanut sauce. My fault for ordering it, but I'm confident that I'd go back and choose something less sucky for my taste buds.

JAWhoPXEwFms_aefCv5GxA.text: I always love coming here and seeing the freshly made noodles and dumplings. The soup dumplings are to die for, as well as the beef onion pancake. Definitely always a favorite!

BDeksESAj4PHmoMWNL2Atw.text: Just tried Everyday Noodles the other night and can't believe I waited so long, this place is really amazing.  First, the Bubble Tea is by far the best I have ever had; I ordered the black milk tea with red bean topping and it was decadent.  Now onto the food selections; we ordered several plates for sharing amongst three people.  *Pork Belly Slider- YUM YUM YUM!  This was more like a full size sandwich on a delicious and soft homemade pancake.  The pork belly was prepared perfectly and had just the right amount of fat to add flavor yet not be greasy.    *Dan-Dan noodles- We ordered the wide flour noodles.  The broth was spicy with a touch of sweetness and topped with peanut paste.  *Pork Soup Dumplings- Large portion and perfect taste!  *Sweet Egg Yolk Steamed Bun-  This was a really good "dessert"!  The buns are  so soft and fresh, but with a duck yolk right in the middle.  The yolk is prepared with honey and vegetable (think of a custard consistency).  I suggest trying Everyday Noodles if you're looking for a perfect balance between authentic and Americanized Chinese/Taiwanese food.  Go ahead, step away from the general tsos.

9fUhcVvaK9O_aXD5yTfKSg.text: Soup dumplings will complete you! Eat all of the soup dumplings you can and then try the potstickers! Ahhhhh so stinking good! I can't believe I've lived on this planet for 30 years without these in my life! I'm sure the rest of the menu is exquisite but I gorge myself on dumplings before I get a chance to partake.

bCrYVpmRwcBDsYa0GSMUKA.text: harsh attitude to my boy of a waitress looking manly, not a wee bit of nice and patience! the food is good

lmOveFhR3PRy2Ki_bq5bFw.text: love this place, various kinds of noodles and dumplings, love the soup dumpling and beef noodles here.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. beef noodles, lots of beef！

P52rb4ygLIroVVbIFzT4cw.text: I have been hearing about this place from many of my coworkers. They all recommend it but I think if you have had soup dumplings in NYC or California, you might be a little disappointed. But for Pittsburgh, this place is really good. They make fresh noodles on site.   I came in and the atmosphere was nice. It's a small restaurant in Squirrel Hill in the busy shopping and food area. The menu was different. You check off what you want and give it to the waitress. I checked off crab and pork soup dumplings, beef and green onion pancake, and a milk green tea with coconut lychee.   First came the beef pancake roll. I really was not a fan. It looks very good and I usually do like scallion pancakes. It was very pretty and I'm sure others will like them a lot.   Then the soup dumplings came as they normally do in a bamboo steamer. I was a little disappointed that a few of the dumplings had their soup seep out before I even opened the steamer. They provide tongs for those who are unable to pick up the dumplings without popping them with chopsticks. I just used my chopsticks and picked them up into my soup spoon and ate them with a little bit of vinegar. They were a little on the bland side but still pretty yummy.   The best part was the bubble tea. I was pleasantly surprised that it was actually milk tea. Other places in Pittsburgh offer bubble tea but they don't actually have tea. The lychee flavor matched perfectly with the tea. The bubbles, however, were mushy with little flavor. I prefer when they are a little bit sweet and cooked firm but not raw and crunchy in the middle.   Pittsburgh is sadly lacking in good Asian cuisine so this place is pretty amazing in that sense.

xJvtO2IDOK4TWJX6NtHORA.text: Watching then make the noodles is a highlight and the pork soup dumplings are great can't wat to go back.

CmVGLaSlIa7SnO9elZ7sXA.text: If you are noise sensitive, this is not the place for you. The men making the noodles slap the dough against the counter as hard as possible, and so there was a constant, extremely loud pounding noise throughout dinner. I started to cringe from this intense pounding noise and left with a headache. (see other comment from guest who said they "jumped" a few times due to the intensity of the noise made from the pounding/slapping of the dough against the counter). My dinner companion  asked a host or waiter if there was any way to lessen the intensity of the noise, and the host/waiter laughed and said no.   .

qYZOmOb90z9ELKernzjMGw.text: I honestly was skeptical. I had never heard of everyday noodles, but my boyfriend wanted to go there. He said they had been voted best noodles in pittsburgh so I wasn't going to turn it down. It lived up to its short reputation with me! I'm not sure if this is considered Korean, Vietnamese, or what type of food but it was amazing! Our waiter was very nice and attentive. Our food came out very fast. We got the servers recommendations - the pork soup dumplings (the soup is IN the dumpling!), he got the Dan Dan noodles Szechuan style and I got the Dan tsun noodles. They all were amazing. His was spicy as mine was not, but we enjoyed both. The only complaints I would have (very minor) was - when we ordered the waiter said "that's not much" and continued to push an appetizer. I was not upset because the dumplings were so amazing but it ended up being A LOT of food for the two of us. We could've split a bowl. The second would be they only set the table with chop sticks and not silverware but I actually enjoyed that, it was just frustrating at points. The noodles ARE HOMEMADE. You can actually watch them make the noodles there, which is pretty neat. One thing I wish I knew ahead of time but will definitely utilize in the future is the fact that it's BYOB! Who doesn't love that?! I really enjoyed the overall atmosphere, service, and loved the food. I give them 5 stars and would highly recommend. It's definitely out of the box, even from the most popular chinese food. Love it & will definitely return!
