K_ihkvDUzWReqqaZtz3zxw.text: The Shanghai dumplings at everyday noodles rival those in LA, SF and Shanghai itself. Pittsburgh is lucky to have it. You know the noodles are fresh because they're literally making them all day in front of the kitchen. My Asian friends all love this place and return often.

RHfUE6bIPCOh-I7lbCGTZA.text: I really enjoyed the beef tendon noodle and steamed dumplings. Would definitely come back again!

eOUs-oKBrmgnS1RBODpw7Q.text: The noodles are fantastic.  Be prepared for a wait to get a seat, but it is worth it.  Watching the noodles made right in front of you was a sight to see.  The soup dumplings were fantastic and the pork and shrimp dumpling soup was also great.  Don't skip on the appetizers as well.  I have not had a bad one yet.

kK9N-MVmhJc2DYVBf167SQ.text: I thought were back in Beijing . . .  Ginnie and I have something of a  tradition on Christmas Eve , , , a movie and dining out . . . usually Asian. This year it was the Manor in Squirrel Hill to see Philomena . . . Judy Dench still at the top of her game, and Everyday Noodles afterwards. They have been since March, but it has taken us a while to get there. Not sure why we waited so long.  The place is a perfect translation of a contemporary noodle shop in Beijing (with some Taiwanese bubble-tea tossed in on the side) to Pittsburgh. Clean, sharp design, open kitchen, fragrant clouds wafting out from the stacked up steamers. It was a very cold night, and we wanted warm and savory. On the menu, Item #42 was Noodles with Minced Pork Sauce. This sounded like one of my favorite Beijing home preparations, Zha jiang mian. I asked our waitress whether this was the dish I was looking for, and, despite my awful pronunciation, she confirmed that it was. It came in minutes and we dug in with gusto. Deep, savory, slightly sweet, a firm foundation based on bean sauce, braised pork and just enough fish stock to deepen the flavor. Slivered cucumbers to balance, and, a surprise, a sprinkling of edamame--a great touch. All over broad wheat noodles. A great start, along with green tea courtesy of Forte. This was a fine beginning, and we decided to finish things off with a scallion pancake, or as the menu describes it #34, Pan Fried Green Onion Pancake. Wow!!; the best I've had since Jinan in Shandong Province, just down the Yellow River from Beijing. Crispy and flaky on the outside, pillowy soft inside, sweet and pungent scallions, piping hot . . . a 10 of 10. So, if you want the best of straight-on Beijing cooking, and don't have 24 hours for a flight to the East, head to Squirrel Hill and Everyday Noodles!

Cv2bW98OFdxU-zbxP3avhQ.text: The noodle soups and soup dumplings are the best in town and some of the best I have ever had. The service on the other hand is very hit or miss. And I don't mind if they want to be cash only but between visits they went from any amount on credit to a 15$ minimum on cards. Overall i highly recommend it but if you are coming by yourself make sure to bring cash or they will make you feel bad for using your card.

MkgDE7yAXE_mZQH3RBWUQA.text: SO AMAZING! Everything is so fresh and made in house -- this includes the noodles! Best asian food in Pittsburgh!

8EvDx49HxDcuyvSdZXPJRQ.text: One of the better shao long bao in the states.  The onion pancakes and pan fried pork buns are done perfect.  The beef noodle soup was good.   Nice little gem in Pittsburgh

FIe5zd6RwYVkY6MvCssCog.text: My favorite place to get bubble tea in the area - I especially love the variety of toppings you can get.

2alt21-2YBBIUtySNueMww.text: This place is usually crowded, but the food is great and close to campus.

ffkU1gXyN6zIdaJuKOpeMQ.text: Almost no options at all for vegetarians, and practically everything has pork in it. This wouldn't be a big issue except that they REFUSE to make any alterations to accommodate their customers, regardless of the reason. They won't add anything or take anything out, which makes no sense at all. I'm not a vegetarian, but I absolutely detest pork, and it is way overused here. Most expensive waste of an experience in a very long time.

fYa5Eb9N04VIk3_U08IX5w.text: I've been there a few times, and I have tried the pork bun, chicken consumme soup, Dan Dan noodles, some kind of noodles with very chewy, not good beef on them, pork and veg potstickers, and the pork soup dumplings.  I'm guessing that this is very traditional taiwanese food and maybe it's just not for me - it's just not a lot of flavor.  However, like every other reviewer, I have to say that the soup dumplings are AMAZING, and I would go back just to eat them.  The pot stickers were good as well, but nothing beats those soup dumplings.  It's also a cool environment and the staff is super friendly.

KMeIeHbXxzJI8YKNvJSVUw.text: Honestly, for the food I will give 4-5 stars. I had some issues with their serving and 2 stars would be fair. We Have been there couple of times, three times we were served with the same waiter, I didn't ask his name. Two of these three times this guy forgot to place part of our orders and let us wait for nothing until I asked him where is my dish. I had been waiting for an hour and got to leave, so asked him to cancel that dish. This guy almost yelled at me: I just placed it for you! The manager was pretty nice and apologized to us, but this guy didn't say anything till the end.  If they still hire this kind of waiters, we will never come back. Their serving doesn't match the high quality of the food, what a shame.

jzcoZyDHWKVJIvJnHVThDQ.text: The hand-made noodles here is awesome! Although the price tag is in average, the noodles taste good and I am satisfied with the food here. Furthermore, the wait time is not a problem because the waitess offered us prompt service. Now this place become where we often hang out in Squirrel Hill area.

Dfa58Y_1P_Hvin0xZ2M4IA.text: This place is ridiculously popular, meaning you're going to have to wait for a table. However, our wait for a table for two at 5pm on a Saturday was only 15 minutes. I don't know what the fuss is all about. Pork short rib noodle soup consomme - the noodles are good, but the soup was fatty (like the short ribs) and not particularly flavorful. The pork soup dumplings were good. The shrimp pork veggie potstickers fell apart easily and had minimal flavor. The broccoli with oyster sauce was good. And my daughter liked her milk mango boba tea.

h7VKC3km80vIu0bbsxqZLA.text: After moving to Pittsburgh from Philadelphia, I was looking for some soup dumplings in Pittsburgh. We heard this place has the best soup dumplings in Pittsburgh so decided to check it out.  Soup dumplings 5/5. They had great flavor and were made fresh right in front of our eyes at their open kitchen window. They were not quite as large as other restaurants I had tried soup dumplings though. Would definitely order them again.   Braised Beef noodle soup 3/5. The braised beef portion was generous and cooked to perfection. The soup on the other hand didn't have much flavor and tasted pretty bland which was disappointing and why I'm giving the soup 3 stars.  Dan Dan noodles Szechuan style 3/5. These were just OK. I also felt they lacked flavor and the portion was on the small side.   Overall, I would come again but would probably try other restaurants before coming back. If I'm really craving soup dumplings, then I would come again for the dumplings.   In a previous visit I had their boba and thought the boba balls were a bit hard which is why we didn't order them again.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Dan Dan Noodles Szechuan Style
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Open kitchen, noodles being made fresh
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pork Soup Dumplings (8)

L-E2fuDw2NqUNq-srjpOvg.text: Just wow. I was absolutely blown away by how good everything was. Coming here was a surprise of sorts. I let the hubby decide where to take me for my birthday and he chose Everyday Noodles. While he has been here multiple times, this was a first for me. Let me tell you, I was definitely not disappointed!   I tend to let my eyes get bigger than my belly, but that was ok in this situation!   We got there hoping it wouldn't be so busy because of the Steeler game, but still ended up with a 20 min wait. Which gave me time to look over the menu and decide what we were going to try.   We decided to try the Pork Soup Dumplings, Braised Beef Noodle Soup, Hot Spicy Wonton Noodles and the Pan Fried Pork Bun.  The Soup Dumplings literally rocked my world. I ate it the American way by just putting it on my soup spoon and sliding it in my mouth. But biting into it is inviting a party into your mouth! The burst of flavors will literally make your mouth so happy. The soup has a great taste as does the little meatball. The whole thing just comes together!  The Braised Beef Noodle Soup was really good as well. It was supposed to be spicy but wasn't spicy enough for me so i got some chili to add to it. still wasn't as spicy as I like but it was still good none the less. It was full of noodles, beef, broccoli and broth.  Hubby had the Wonton Noodles so I can't really review them but he sad they were really good.  The Pan Fried Pork Bun was pretty good as well. Crispy, the pork was tender and full or flavor. Even better when dipped in the soy sauce. They were so good that even though I was full, I had to eat them all!  All in all it was a great trip and a great experience! I definitely recommend coming here!

3DASTD0_i-x97br97cJC0g.text: This is the best place I have found to get soup dumplings in Pittsburgh. We got the pork soup dumplings and the Dan Dan noodles. They were both pretty good.  This place is BYOB with a small corkage fee, but as an FYI I'd suggest planning where to pick up booze in advance since the closest beer/wine/liquor stores I could find were a few blocks away on Murray Ave.  I would also recommend trying to sit somewhere you can watch the cooks making the noodles and dumplings. It's really fun to watch!

FFQNXPZ4BFzBhGl1g-gDHg.text: This is my favorite go-to spot to eat! If there is a wait, you won't have to wait long. Their service is so speedy. There have been times we sat down, ordered and food was on the table within 5 minutes.   You can watch the chefs making noodles and dumplings from the dining area. It is cool to see!  My favorite items to order are the pork soup dumplings, pork belly over rice and the Dan Dan noodles. I have never ordered the Bubble Tea but friends have and they love it!  Ive gotten take out from here and the food is always ready quickly and packaged up nicely.   Highly recommend everyone checking this place out!!

O4UT2xwv9C_HYiKgDPlP9g.text: Came here for the first time for lunch on a Saturday.  I ordered the tofu nuggets as an appetizer, the stir fried watercress with oyster sauce, and the beef noodle soup with tendon (wide noodles).  I ordered take out of their jellyfish appetizer and wood ear mushrooms with tofu skins.  What's Hot - Quality.  Delish!  I ordered their classic beef noodle soup with tendon, which is a traditional Taiwanese Chinese dish.  They asked if I wanted chili oil and I declined.  The mark of any good noodle soup is the broth.  If the broth is well seasoned and savory, that's a good sign.  This broth was flavorful and already had a slight spicy kick.  Additionally, their beef chunks and tendons are tender and stewed before hand.  I could definitely taste that.  They also asked me if I wanted my noodles wide or thin.  May not make sense to those who aren't Chinese food aficionados, which is cool.  But for me, that they ask is great.  I like the texture of my noodles thicker and chewy.  Gives it better flavor.  There was even a slice of daikon in my soup!  Definitely awesome.  Their stir fried watercress wasn't too oily, either.  All the food was well seasoned.   - Menu.  Classic Taiwanese Chinese dishes- jellyfish, seaweed salad, green onion pancakes, milk tea, etc...  Their menu is like Goldilocks- just right.  It's not overwhelming.  Additionally, if you have any questions about their menu items, their wait staff can answer your questions.  They're knowledgeable and helpful. - Service.  Fast and efficient.  I asked for 2 of my appetizers for takeout when I gave the waitress my order.  She had it ready at my table before my check came.  There was also a pair of chopsticks in there, too.  This place is definitely buzzing, especially because the layout is small.   - Price.  Reasonable, but can add up.  Most of the items on their menu are less than $10.  A handful of items are over $11, but not many.  However, their portions aren't family size- they're not huge.  Sharing works between 2 people, but that's it.   - Location.  It's in the heart of Squirrel Hill, which means easy accessibility.  There are plenty of other shops and restaurants around; all within walking distance.  What's Not - Parking.  There is street parking and the little side lots behind the other shops.  However, parking here is not easy when it's busy (ex: weekends). - Price.  Prices here are reasonable, but they can add up, especially if you come in a group.  For example, my total (3 appetizers, 1 veggie, and 1 noodle soup) came out a little over $40. - Layout.  This place is not good for groups.  I saw one large round table in the very back that can seat over 4 people (I think it's 8-10 people).  I don't recommend coming here with a group of over 4 people.  Their tables are for 2, which means they can accommodate groups if they push the tables together.  This means that if you come with a group of 2 or more, you're waiting.  Final Answer Willing to come back, but come first thing on a weekend to avoid the parking hassle and the wait.

0gmrPZilk1PbJqEqgIIMKA.text: This place is easily one of my new favorite noodle shops. Everyday Noodles gets very crowded (which can be a downside), but it is all for good reason. The food is unbelievable. The flavor is just so authentic, and every main dish is made fresh and in house. I split the cold sesame noodles, the pork soup dumplings, and the pancake cucumber beef rolls between myself and another person. It was the perfect amount of food. 10/10 recommend the pork soup dumplings - I've never had anything like it.  Uniquely, Everyday Noodles displays the noodle making process upfront so that you can see the labor behind your dish. It can get noisy, but it's definitely an experience worth trying.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

b8HknUe7bADKZFe8x8FPfg.text: Stopped by here earlier this week for a date after he recommended it and I have to say this place is delicious! It's pretty small and crowded but we were able to be seated right away.   We got an order of soup dumplings, which were absolutely delicious and fun to eat. I myself ordered the beef and tendon noodle soup with wide flour noodles. It was delicious and the portions were generous for the price. The broth was so flavorful and well seasoned.  Also extra points because the date went swimmingly well (haha). The atmosphere here is a little nice but still casual so it makes it a nice date spot. Service was really nice and attentive; not to mention our food came out pretty freaking fast! Hope to come here again sometime soon!

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Beef and Braised Beef and Tendon Noodle Soup

bdgOYJI_-T7aeNtQfSpd6g.text: The noodles themselves (we got the thin noodles) were very good, and so were the soup dumplings and wontons in my spicy wonton noodles. However, the spicy noodles did not have much flavor at all, they were basically like plain noodles but with a more slick texture because of the oil. I would rate the level of spiciness at a 3/10. They are a little bit spicy but nothing that is going to make you down glasses of water.   Service at our table was very fast and attentive. A server even saw me (pathetically) struggle with my chopsticks and came over with a little plastic device to help my child self hold the chopsticks.   We were seated at a big, round table with a group of three people on the other side to save space. The table was so big that our separate groups had very decent personal space. Prices were very reasonable as well, with most items being $7-9. I will probably not come again, but only because I tried everything I was interested in on the menu.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Seating

Q8g5fFj3Kh9_-kUMtGe9ig.text: I would undoubtedly give the beef 5 stars, and everything else a 3-4. The beef was melt in your mouth tender and flavorful, as far as the rest of the soup I was 'okay' with the noodles. I think maybe the mind blowing was left out of my meal. Is this place more hype than substance? Service was quick and friendly. Not much explanation was given about the menu. I would like to go back and give the dumplings a try, since they come highly reviewed as well.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

f4Am74731uZDwX-seVrlXw.text: Went on a Friday night around 7:30 and it was packed! Even then, they were able to seat a table of five within thirty minutes. They sat us right in front of the window where you can see the chef make traditional dumplings and it was awesome. Service was quick but I definitely didn't feel rushed. BYOB for a $5 corking fee per table.   The soup dumplings were amazing and I can't wait to go get them again.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Soup Dumplings

PPpKeMJqMl3omnbgkDEMkg.text: Everyday Noodles is HANDS DOWN my favorite restaurant in Pittsburgh. If you go, you absolutely need to get the Pork Soup Dumplings because it is heaven in a spoon. If you add a little ginger to them you can hear angels sing.  My go-to aside from the dumplings are the Dan-Dan Noodles Szechuan Style with thin noodles. It's delicious, savory with a lil heat to it. The noodles with Mince Pork Sauce are also exceptional.   Overall, the food is incredible, the service is fast and friendly, and it's a cute & intimate atmosphere. Definitely a cute date spot. The only thing is that it can get crowded during peak hours, so plan ahead.

j74JAhtCpPDLAgh1yUMQYg.text: Everyday noodles is a great place if you are looking for dumplings or noodles (or bubble tea). They also have a takeout option.  Initially suggested by a friend, I've been here 5/6 times and I keep coming back.  Typically I order some soup dumplings to share and then some rice or dry noodles. Watching the chefs creating the noodles in the open kitchen while you're having dinner is very pleasant.  They don't take reservations, so you might have to wait. It's usually pretty crowded.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Dry DanTsu noodles

BK_HeJvr8TJEzeiIKZWQZA.text: Delicious all the time, I'm a NYC gal, moved to Pittsburgh and was seeking a place like I would find in China Town and this is it.  soup dumplings are my favorite, loved the scallion pancakes. All their noodle dishes are  made there, veggies fresh and still crips when served to you.  I go back as often as i am able and when in the neighborhood.

6dqVr6Bih9yYPz7vakb05w.text: So in China there is a pun - Tian Tian Jian Mian (Everyday Noodles) sounds the same as Everyday we meet, only written differently.   Handcrafted fresh noodles with amazing texture, I tried the Wonton noodles and they were amazing, it goes really well with the chilly paste, also made from scratch.   My friends ordered a bunch of vegetarian sides, golden tofu, mushroom and tofu skins, watercress and of course the dumplings.   Plenty of vegetarian options and customizable. They also have boba.   Highly recommend it if you are in Pittsburg.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

ReBLJ-TUd1Zind4NROWbuw.text: My family and I came here for my birthday dinner.  We read the great reviews and decided to try it.  The atmosphere was neat.  The men behind the glass were making homeade noodles and dumplings which was pretty amazing.  However, our waitress was 0 learns to treat people with respect and to give ALL people good service. We went across the street to the Ramen Bar and were treated like royalty.  Sorry not sorry

DMSataKYZZTghNmc-UJmZA.text: Everyday Noodle has a decent take on the ever so popular (but still underrated) traditional Chinese broth noodles.  I like their beef noodle soup, as those usually bring out the best of their flavors, and have some decently cooked eyes of beef and tendon. The soup is savory, and the noodles, although not hand-pulled, go well with the overall bowl.  As for the other items, I'm not as impressed. Their appetizers always are a let down because they taste just bland and funky.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Beef tendon noodle soup
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Wide noodles
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Disappointing cold chicken appetizer...

_YSgnxQ5APfJYIfamA1A2w.text: I drive 30 miles out of county for this Wonderful Restaurant! The Mango Tea Milk, Pork Soup Dumplings, and a Soup, or Dry Noodle dish.  It's worth the drive to the Squirrel Hill section of Pittsburgh.  Afterwards, walk a few doors down to Gaby et Jules, a French Patisserie.

kEa9xF739kBAlsc3jz_f6Q.text: I love the quality of the noodles here! They make it in house and you can watch the chefs making it in the back.   I unfortunately didn't get to eat here as often as I would like but when I visit Pittsburgh, I would love to go here again!

HPyyReafwGO9PIceqHL-Qw.text: My friend and I sought to satiate our craving for asian food, and we are pleased to say that we definitely satisfied our appetite, but our craving, perhaps...Overall the service at this petite shop is amazing, and the overall dining experience was delightful.  We ordered three dishes: beef tendon soup, pork dumplings, and green onion pancake. The soup was absolutely delicious! The tendon is so tender I felt that it could melt in my mouth (although this isn't my preference, it was amazing to see tendon become this delicate!). The soup and beef were both flavorful; the noodles were a bit bland but the texture was spot on.  Dumplings were a bit doughy (which I enjoy) although we were surprised that they didn't have as much soup within. Nevertheless they were delicious.  My friend and I were torn between the pancakes. They were crispy on the outside, doughy inside. I like doughy textures, sometimes, but my friend did not enjoy this.  Lastly, the interior is quite modern, very clean, and overall provided a great dining atmosphere. As a result the small interior I can imagine the ambient noise getting loud during a busy night. We enjoyed a pleasantly mellow evening.

3yTpL_SYWBwR8hfGmBBfPg.text: Hands down the most authentic Taiwanese food in town :) I come here so often when I miss Taiwanese food. I tried so many things on the menu, and so far none of the item fail to satisfy me. When my friends are in town visiting I always bring them to everyday noodles, and they all love it very much. We all go home with our tummy happy! The place could of be bigger because of how popular they are. However, solid five stars for them, because of the amazing food and also for how fast their service is. The wait on the weekend is long but worth it! :)

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pork buns! Yum
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. My typical order. Pork soup dumplings and beef noodle soup

osSBDDRZwjalfYR9IkeUTQ.text: Love the food here - highly recommend the oxtail noodle soup, chicken noodle soup and the potstickers...

xtJtMd8tl3KYF4hHPUe76w.text: THE BEST RAMEN IN PITTSBURGH. Period.   Soup dumplings are incredible.  My go-to is the spicy beef bowl.   I drive TO squirrel hill FOR this place. Delicious.

c0u-mGn2xyHP2FIsKdYmKQ.text: Just had lunch there with the family. We are trying out the Chinese food in Pittsburgh so that the little sister has an idea of what Asian food there is out here. We do not want her deprived now that she is coming out to Pittsburgh. We were at Rose Tea Cafe and saw this place and tried it today. I would highly recommend them!  I was thoroughly disappointed. The soups were all bland. Braised beef noodle soup, oxtail noodle soup, lamb... Even the gua bao was terrible. The peanuts overpowered the whole bao. I would not recommend this place...I hope that it was just a bad day or the standards for good Chinese food is low out here.  I give it two stars for service and the xiao long bao. Service is quick. The xiao long bao was quite good.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Bland braised beef noodle soup.

X2mMAVAOiQXPq13wqK78oQ.text: Food_ Their spice is quite exotic, so I wasn't so fond of this place, but I heard a pretty good comments about Everyday's Noodle's from many of my friends. Seeing how they make noodles is very entertaining, and it makes me appreciate what I am eating a bit more.   BOBA_ The richest bubble tea! And RED BEAN taste!! I like their bubble tea the most. But I don't think they wash their blender quite well. In my green tea bubble tea I always taste red bean.

t_1EIXMRaL_bKQYmOH2Omg.text: Our favorites are jelly fish salad (fresh and crispy), wood ear & tofu skin, braised beef and tendon noodle soup (very tender and flavorful, love tendon!), rolled onion pancake with sliced beef, and shrimp and loofah soup dumpling (only offered on Sundays).  Bubble tea with grass jelly and red bean are awesome!  What I don't care much are pork soup dumpling (the soup inside is not very flavorful and kinda salty), #41 shrimp/pork/veg wonton, and potstickers.  They are not bad, but just so so.  If you look for authentic Chinese with high quality food and less grease, this is the place to go.  Be prepared to wait for 20-30 minutes because this place is small.

GmfXahQXPVYwXvXkFPYmTQ.text: This place gets everything right. Speed. Quality. Prices. Both for a nice dinner and a quick lunch. Great service. Everything made with care, professionalism, and a homemade feel.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

OUkcA7XnAFYeKksL4kx1MQ.text: Living in Pittsburgh, one thing I really miss is waking up on a weekend morning and grabbing dim sum with friends. There is no real dim sum in Pittsburgh. It's a sad reality we have to live with. However, given that restriction, Everyday Noodles does a pretty damn good job with dumplings and potstickers.   When you walk in, you are greeted with the noise of chatter and the pounding of fresh noodles. I was in the mood for dumplings and potstickers though, so I skipped these (for now), and got the pork & crab meat soup dumplings. These are sooo good, you can really taste every element, the pork, the crab, the soup, and as someone who generally doesn't love too much ginger (sorry for those who do), the ginger flavor isn't so strong and the whole thing is soothing and delicious.  We also got the shrimp, pork, and vegetable potstickers. Crispy fried goodness on the outside and cooked to perfection on the inside.  Speaking of dim sum, I haven't tried their shumai, but these dishes are so good, that I'll definitely be back to try more and more! I'm especially excited about their fresh noodle dishes. Until next time :)

F6SyxQCCy1rwYQq-pcvRqA.text: Everyday Noodles is amazing. All of the Noodles are made in house.  I can't even list a recommendation for a noodle or dim sum. They are truly all that good.  As a note, they don't do spicy. If you're looking for spicy, you will be disappointed. The spicy dishes aren't spicy.

UBlEyV8M3K3VzP4exP8OuA.text: Get here early because this place is always packed! I love the layout of the restaurant--clean and bright. While waiting, you can watch the chef at work making fresh noodles and wontons through a glass display window. The best part is seeing how your food is made and knowing that it's fresh!   I ordered the dry dan tsu noodles. I didn't care much for the meat or vegetables, the noodles itself was phenomenal. You get a choice between small or large noodles. Small looks like spaghetti and large is flat and wide. I got the large noodles and would recommend the large noodles since you'll be able to taste the noodles more (the main part). The sauce and seasoning were average, but the noodles stole the show. Unlike generic noodles that tend to get soggy or rubbery, these special hand tossed noodles from Everyday Noodles have this nice firm and doughy texture.   If you are a noodles fan, I highly recommend this place--for both the food and the learning experience.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Shrimp and pork wonton noodle soup
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Beef tendon noodle soup
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. dry dan tsu noodles

kJurWkx6NrhACr-Yn61YNA.text: Modern, clean facilities with a great view of chefs creating hand made noodles and dumplings. We ordered various potstickers and steamed dumplings, all of which were excellent and delicious.  Staff was kind and attentive. We will likely be back, and with friends.

geNTOlQNw4Hxkw5f4QdnCw.text: Best soup dumplings I've ever had in US! My boyfriend is a huge fan to their hot spicy wonton noodles.  Their desserts are my favorite. Sweet bean pancakes and sesame rice ball are amazingly good.

92N4gH_wGJP66rlkfg1ZnA.text: So good. So so good. Everything is fresh, generously portioned, and affordable! Have not had a bad meal here and it is my go-to place to take any visiting folks. I personally prefer noodle soups - especially in the colder seasons, so I'd recommend those, but their cold noodles are also very good! Their hot wonton noodles were great - ma la spice, so I had to have a beverage to wash it down with. And of course, the soup dumplings are very delicious and great for sharing :)

i1IMhsYrbVcTzs533_tILw.text: Good noodles but sad, tired soup broth made with no love....add a little ginger? cilantro? spring onions? love?

AOMsIbm6tljw65N_1c3x7A.text: Everything is so good here. I started with the pork soup dumplings. Little pockets with big flavor. I love the concept of soup inside the dumplings. Every one is like you favorite bite of soup. From there I had the dan dan Szechuan noodles. I felt a need to add some chicken to it which at first seemed like a bad idea. The chicken was shredded and plain, so it didn't fit. But after a few minutes soaking in the spicy peanutty sauce, it was another layer of awesome. The fresh wide noodles have bite, and flavor and chew. Wow. So good, and hearty and tasty. I finished with the onion pancake wrapped beef. Another flavorful experience. Will be back. Probably tomorrow night!

U-eu87epLWBkLC7opXk9DA.text: We came here on a Saturday around opening time. I would recommend getting to the restaurant around 15min earlier than the opening time because there was already a line to get in (before the restaurant even opened). There was a cool section of the restaurant where they have their chefs making the noodles. Overall the service speed was normal and the employees were friendly. The food was all very delicious and I would definitely recommend coming here!

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Menu
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. My sister and I at the restaurant!
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Noodles with minced pork sauce // 炸醬麵

bZktRLLjP1kYc9p0j6U5Lg.text: Not bad Pittsburgh, not bad. Everyday Noodles exceeded my expectations of Asian food in Pittsburgh! Since I'm from the Bay Area, which is filled with TONS of good Asian food, I didn't have high hopes for the Asian food in Pittsburgh, but this place is definitely not bad!  Pros: Most of the food is very good. Not the best, but I was still very impressed. The xiao long bao (pork soup dumplings) are pretty good. We got 3 or 4 noodle soups and all of them were good. We also ordered broccoli with minced pork sauce and that was good too! The decor is nice and modern, and seems pretty clean.   Cons: We got one of their milk teas and it was not very good. It had a weird, kinda watered-down taste to it, so I didn't drink much of it. The service was also just okay. They left out our order of minced pork sauce over rice, but it was okay because we were all too full anyway.   Overall: If I lived in Pittsburgh, Everyday Noodles would be one of my go-to places for Asian food! The only thing stopping me from giving it 5 stars is that it's not as good as the food in California, but it definitely is impressive for Pittsburgh!

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Coffee milk tea...not that good
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. All our food!
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Beef noodle soup

pNqAgZ6p_SfOBG6um0ekmQ.text: Good meal. Didn't expect this level of Chinese food in Pittsburgh.  Had soup dumplings and beef soup noodle. Noodles are hand made and fresh. Dumplings were good, and most of times you can't go too wrong with soup dumplings.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Soup dumplings
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Dumpling men

ctIHsZurpt3lq8xWjjctaQ.text: In a nutshell: authentic Chinese noodles made in-house. Assortment of dumplings too.   I've been here several times and I can't say I'm entirely impressed. Although it's neat to watch the cooks make the noodles right in front of you, they seem to use the same dough for everything on their menu, which makes it easy for them to offer such a variety. However, everything I've tried just seems to taste the same because they use that same dough for everything. If you get one dumpling, you've tried them all. I've tried the potstickers, soup dumplings and pan-fried dumplings. They taste the same, just depends if you're in the mood for fried and crispy or steamed and soggy. In terms of noodles, of course the broths and toppings change the flavor but something about the ones I've tried are still so similar. I've tried the Dan tsu, Dan Dan and spicy wonton. Of the three, I like the spicy wonton most. Dan tsu has a strong 5 spice flavor and Dan Dan, I'm not a fan. Their Dan Dan noodles have a strong peanut butter taste and although that's a key ingredient, I don't think it should overpower all the other flavors.   However, I do like the bubble teas. Their bubble teas aren't overly sweetened and I like that you have the option of getting an additional topping other than tapioca. They have grass jelly and red bean which I haven't seen at many other bubble tea places.   All in all, the food is decent but I wish there was more a variety of flavors. I will continue to try new dishes each time, seeking for something that stands out from the rest of the menu.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Wontons
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pork soup dumplings
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Noodles with minced pork

tV_AtJCZmoqO2uxHnJXaiw.text: Blegh.  Since it seems that I've read that plenty of people think is legit authentic and great, I'm just going to write this review for the noodle soup. Part of me feels bad for giving such low stars for a small subsection of the menu, but I'm sorry, it was just that bad.  My husband ordered take out for us from here. I just told him to just order for me. He "played it safe" and got one beef and one chicken noodle soup. This was the blandest most boring soup ever. The stock itself was full of flavor of the meat, but that was it. It was terrifyingly simple in its flavor profile. However, what was the worst was the meat! My husband's beef was gigantic beef pieces that he had to fish out of his bowl and cut on the side to eat. I had whole chicken legs simply simmered in the broth. You know how the underside of the turkey's skin is always gross and rubbery and not all flavorful and crispy like the roasted top? That's what this horrible chicken in my soup was like (on top of being tons of gristle and fat). Noodles were simply bland and this was just all around disapointing :(((  To be honest, I don't know if I'll try this place again, but mayyyyybeeeee I might and NEVER get the noodle soups. idk, if you think this review isn't fair to the restaurant, just take it at "don't get the noodle soups, get everything else that other people mention is good."

aT5BP-hM7Gahcn9OCB3V4Q.text: Waited for 40min+ before six o clock.. The zhajiangmian is a bit too salty. The bok choy is a good amount of food

1jNUpNGfIZIby1Wa1SWYOw.text: Arrived at 2pm on a Sunday afternoon and were seated right away at the only empty table.  Food arrived very quickly!  We got the pork soup dumplings, pork belly slider, and thin noodles with minced pork sauce.  Dumplings were as good as any I've had in NYC.  The gua bao was huge, but that was the only thing impressive about it.  Noodles were freshly made and tasted great!  I'd want to try the wider noodle next time.  We also got a green milk tea, which was much creamier (and tastier) than across the street.  Would definitely come by if we're in the area again!

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pork soup dumplings, pork belly slider, minced pork noodles, and green milk tea

lIoRitJgzT-zlX9uHQY3Wg.text: Everyday Noodles is probably the best place to enjoy Chinese noodles and wrapped dumpling offerings in Pittsburgh. There is usually a line waiting to be seated, but the clientele, kitchen and service staff moves quickly so the wait is usually not terrible.   The service has always been quick and professional.  The lamian (handpulled noodles), were cooked perfectly were provided just enough bite. The minced pork sauce noodles are also very flavorful. The shrimp and pork wonton noodle soup is also very good.   The pork soup dumplings are very juicy, and the shrimp-pork shaomais offer that nice crunch that you expect from shrimp (although at times you lose the bottom side of the dumpling skin and much of the liquid flavorful goodness in the steamer liner).   Portions were generous and the prices are very reasonable.  The owner, Michael Chen, can often be spotted in the restaurant and often asked customers whether they enjoyed their meals while removing their empty plates and bowls. I think that is always a good sign for a restaurant.

32P1OxQDI7TD-ukBJt0pzA.text: fantastic! Soup dumplings were incredible. Have been to a few authentic Asian dim sum style restaurants in Toronto Canada and this is up there with them. Highly recommend this place.  I liked this place enough to post my 1st review in 4 years of using yelp.

SzQXWW19qtujBnKrGfe3iA.text: I stopped in here especially to try their soup dumplings that I heard so much about. When I walked in what kind of threw me off was the smell, it smelled like mold or mildew. I ordered the pork dumplings and scallion pancake, both were served hot. I did like them but I must say its not really authentic. Probably won't be returning.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Chili oil and soy sauce

p1fDiWir8hIJDlIzlOlELQ.text: I went here twice in three days.  That's normal, right?  On a Saturday, I went in for a little snack to go.  I wanted to check out their Siu Mai (pork dumplings and shrimp) and their potstickers.  Both were amazing.  My wife and kids and I gobbled it up.  The Siu Mai had a balanced seafood and pork flavor.  The potstickers (pork and vegetable) were a perfect crispy texture but not dripping with oil and incredibly tasty.  So, on Monday, we ventured back but went for a sit down meal.  Here's what we ended up with: Pork Soup Dumplings ($9) Pork and Vegetable Potstickers ($8) Vegetable Dumplings ($9) Shrimp, Pork and Vegetable Wontons - Szechuan Style ($6) Taiwanese Style Sesame Cold Noodles - ($6) Side of steamed rice - ($2)  I thought the veggie dumplings were just meh.  But everything else was just perfect.  Be sure to try the pork soup dumplings and their potstickers!  A real surprise was the Taiwanese sesame cold noodles.  I liked the peanut and vinegar balance.  It's not for everyone but I really enjoyed it.  We finished up at $52 with drinks, tax and tip.  Service was friendly and attentive.  We were seated in a long bench facing where the dumplings were being made.  Talk about dinner and a show!  This was a ton of fun for the kids and our whole family ate well.  Can't wait to be back again!  The only knock about this place - it's too small!  There are only about 36 or so seats in this place and if you don't get there early, you will be waiting for a while.  We got in right as lunch was picking up and no wait for a table.  Others coming in after us were not as lucky - so be aware.

abHGTIw_IT0ZxE-saSaV4A.text: This is a really high-quality restaurant. Some of my super-picky Chinese friends poo-poo it, but many other friends love it. I'm a fan, and I've truly enjoyed the good service that I've received here, as well as the food. And the spectacle of seeing fresh noodles made.   In addition to this place having some authentic dishes that aren't readily available elsewhere, I took a friend who doesn't know authentic Chinese food from a hole in the wall, and she keeps asking me to take her back.

FN4nvk2Ju9fuGUCbuFY2EQ.text: Favorite place to get delivery from. I especially enjoy their pork soup dumpling, and I feel like their bubble tea is probably one of the best in town.

n47tbhgxYy0sgk0ZxF7aoQ.text: Terrific food, I've eaten there at least a dozen times and every time it's been amazing.  I've tried everything on the menu & here are some of my favorites:    Pork Belly Slider- it's a damn fine sandwich.  Simple, cheap, makes a great lunch.   Pork Soup Dumplings- Just magical slurpy amazing Wood Ears & Tofu Skins- nice little snack with great texture.   Potstickers- these are real potstickers that you pull apart, not just glorified dumplings

CG63NEMsglqdFxRuInBowQ.text: Another great addition to the asian food scene in Pittsburgh, which seems to be heating up! My husband and I were so excited in the months leading up to the opening, because I have always lamented the lack of really good, authentic Chinese food in Pittsburgh (although try Sichuan Gourmet for Sichuan food, and Orient Kitchen for Cantonese). When I heard that they had xiao long bao, I knew that I had to come.   I've been twice now, and have thoroughly enjoyed myself both times. While the xiao long bao isn't as good as those you might get at Joe Shanghai's in NYC or in LA, it's probably one of the few, if ONLY, places you can get them in Pittsburgh. And for that, I give them immense gratitude for giving me access to one of my favorite things to eat. For this alone, I give them five stars. The potstickers are also very large and tasty. My personal favorite noodle dish is the noodles with minced pork. The noodles are perfectly tender, and every bite is just super tasty.   Now, do I think this place is as good as the places in NYC or LA? No. But for Pittsburgh, this is probably the best. So, for example, as some of the other reviewers have mentioned, the braised noodle beef soup could pack a little more punch (in fact, I think Ice Tea Taipei down the street might do a little better in this department. But if you're not familiar with asian food, I think Ice Tea Taipei is kind of hard to navigate). Part of the issue is that they are catering both to people who don't have a lot of experience with Asian cuisine, while also trying to satisfy those of us who have expectations for what they should do or how things should taste. It's a fine line to walk, and I think that they do a good job of it.  The service is friendly and fast, and I love the open kitchen. If you don't want to see how your food is made, go somewhere else. But for those of us who want to be in touch with those who produce the meal, the open kitchen gives you a great peek into what goes into each dish. Come and try it!  p.s. not super veggie friendly. They do have some options, but they are extremely limited. I hear that they are going to try and change that, but just something to keep in mind.

lLMef0S_D7p9rvr9sCYL6w.text: I was predisposed to liking Everyday Noodles based on the cute pun in its name -- in Chinese, the word for "noodles" is a homonym with the word for "face," so a common phrase that means "we see each other ['s face] everyday" sounds the same as "we see noodles everyday." Then I found out that they are going to serve soupy dumplings (xiao long bao; henceforth, XLB for short), which is my absolute favorite comfort food. When I go back to LA or Taiwan, I always make multiple pilgrimages to the mecca of XLBs: Ding Tai Fun (yelp.com/biz/din-tai-fun...). A good XLB should have a delicately thin but al dente skin; it should be dainty enough that it fits in one bite; and it should, above all, be piping hot (to the point of mouth burning) and bursting with juicy broth. I thought that if Everyday Noodles' XLB is anywhere near half as good as Ding Tai Fun's, I'd be thrilled. Everyday Noodles's XLB is more than half as good as Ding Tai Fun's. I'm willing to bet that in a blind taste test, we'd find Everday and DTF in a statistical tie with 95% confidence. Everyday runs on the same formula as DTF: a glass box kitchen that showcases the chefs making the dumplings in the front; pencils/paper order forms and efficient service, bright and cheerful decor, and sadly, a long long looooooong wait line. DTF is so famous in California that people drive up from San Diego and down from the North to eat there. Waiting for an hour or two (even if you showed up at 5pm on a week night) was just the rite of passage to XLB nirvana. At Everyday Noodles, we waited for 50 minutes, after showing up at 6:45 on a Friday night. By Pittsburgh standard, this is a bit on the long side, but DTF has trained me to wait it out. In the end, I'm glad our patience was rewarded. Other than the XLBs (both pork and crabmeat&pork), there are also regular dumplings, several noodle dishes, and a few standard Chinese restaurant stuff (stir fry veggies, etc.). Of the two types of XLBs, we liked the pork-only a bit better than the crab/pork mix. The veggie dumplings are also excellent, though not quite at the level of DTF's. For the noodle dishes, we tried both the dan-dan (cold) and the pork sauce (hot). Both are very good (fresh pasta just tastes better), but I'd rather save more room for various dumplings. We also ordered some Chinese watercress in oyster sauce and an eggplant appetizer (cold); they are fine, but they are common place. Desserts are surprisingly good. Again, eat everything while it's hot! All in all, this is a wonderful new addition to Pittsburgh. It is easily the best Chinese noodle shop this side of the continental US. If not for the (likely to grow) long lines, I really just might go see them everyday.

WmFMbNZrQpcUAYtpWOXiTw.text: We went on a Saturday night, the wait was about 20 minutes which seems to be average.   We ordered the Pork Soup Dumplings which came out right away and were delicious. I had the Dan Dan Noodles Szechuan Style which were also very good. We brought our own bottle of wine- the uncorking fee was only $5.   The only negative thing I have to say is that the room was very loud and the tables were close together. However, this is pretty unavoidable on a Saturday night.

EyaJffNegYlXPFJwBY2UaQ.text: At the risk of sounding repetitive, the main allure of this place is the soup dumplings (XLBs) finally making their entrance on the Pittsburgh food scene.  They came out steaming and piping hot - 2 flavors to choose from (pork or pork and crab.)  The homemade, hand-stretched noodles were also excellent and chewy and doughy (with pork sauce on top.)    The ambiance was also very nice with noodle-themed wall decor.  Half of the diners get to watch a good view of the kitchen show, the other half are not so lucky.  Be prepared to hear the details of conversations all around you though.  So, if you've been longing to get XLBs in Pittsburgh, go here, and if you have no idea what those are, go here and find out!  Either way you're good!

iSZ0JsXmONblGmCUEGitFw.text: Amazing food! I always love the soup dumplings and the fried tofu. The tofu crust actually stays on the tofu when you bite into it (it doesn't slide off like at other places). Service is quick and easy. The only bad thing about this place is its size; if they somehow expanded it wouldn't be packed as quickly as usual.

JHFNr25ZsMZY5Pcel3nS2A.text: Wow! My wife and I went to the opening night of Everyday Noodles and we are so happy to have this authentic dumpling and noodle restaurant in Squirrel Hill. We tried the Pork Soup Dumplings (Xiao Long Bao; amazing ), the veggie dumplings (delicious), the Noodles with Minced Pork Sauce (our favorite of the night), Baby Bok Choy (some of the best I've had), and Sweet Bean Paste Crispy Pancakes for dessert (a wonderful way to end the meal). All this was eaten while watching the chefs make the dumplings and noodles from scratch through the open kitchen.   What's really amazing is that on opening night this place was packed! We were lucky and didn't have to wait, but by the time we were finished, there was a line waiting to taste the amazing food. Honestly, if we had to wait, we absolutely would.   If you're in the area and you want some hand made delicious dumplings and/or noodles, definitely give this place a try. Oh, they also have ramen-like soups, but we'll have to go again to try those!

dobrhbpdxTMh9EWiTEQk7A.text: The owners are very nice and friendly. I can see that they are really trying to make the business work. I'm personally not a fan of lining up for a popular restaurant. I like places that I can make a reservation and sit in a quiet environment. My husband really wanted to try the place, so we lined up for about 0.5 hrs, which I think it's not worth the time.  The food still has a lot of room for improvement.

alxca0C7GyrpzKkGu6vBGQ.text: Not good for vegetarians. The vegetarian noodles (labeled as such) on the daily specials board was actually cooked in a meat broth.   This place gets points for having good and courteous waiters who pointed it out when we were ordering. We were able to leave and go somewhere more vegetarian friendly.

e4Nds_i31E7uyscQUVkRlA.text: Soup dumplings. That's what lured me in you can't get them in Pittsburgh and it's a huge oversight. If you aren't aware, soup dumplings are magical. They are basically a steamed pork dumpling with broth inside. You have to eat them off of a spoon so you don't lose the broth when you bite into it.   Since these are the only soup dumplings in the city, they are the best in town. However, not the best I've ever had. Again, more expensive thank what you'd pay for them in larger cities. The pork tasted a bit like sausage, which seemed just wrong. I prefer to taste the ginger and scallion that usually accompanies the pork in a dumpling.   My noodle dish, was flavorful, but contained only noodles. No meat. No vegetables. A bit disappointing if you're looking for a dish with variety.   The pork belly "sliders" are nothing but. You get one, and its huge. You need a fork and knife to eat it. The pork belly could have been rendered more as it was a little chewy, but the flavor was good.   This can get me through any soup dumpling cravings here, but will need a trip to NYC or Philly for the real deal.

1n4sR33H0g70vIYriFwdBQ.text: I was at Pittsburgh for work for a few days, and driving into the city and craving Chinese food, Yelp led me to this place. This place serves pretty authentic Chinese food including a lot of different noodles and soup dumplings for a really reasonable price.   The place was pretty busy when we came in at around 7pm on a Sunday, and we waited for about 15 minutes. The inside of the restaurant is long and narrow and goes pretty far back. It has about two columns of tables and they're all pretty close together. We sat at an end table, and because the restaurant is so busy, it actually kind of felt like restaurants in China where there're people everywhere.  There is also an glass window where you can see people in the kitchen making the noodles.   There were two of us, and we ordered the eggplant appetizer, the beef noodle soup, one order of the soup dumplings, and noodles with minced pork sauce (zha jiang mian). Personally, I think the wide noodles taste better. The eggplant was cooked super soft and smothered in a garlic bean paste sauce. It's one of the best eggplant dish I've had in a while, especially that sauce! The beef noodle soup came in a giant bowl. It's one of the pricier items on the menu, at about $12 or so, and totally worth it. It also had a lot of beef chunks, which is different than some other places that only gives us like 3-4 chunks of beef. My zha jiang mian was also super delicious. The pork was a little too minced, but overall I still loved it. And then there was the soup dumplings! It didn't have as much soup as I liked, but the flavor was really good. Honestly, considering the slim pickings around DC where I'm from, I'm not super picky when it comes to soup dumplings.   The place was cheap, and the best part, it takes credit card. I hate that a lot of very authentic Chinese places only takes cash. If I lived in Pittsburgh, I'd come back here a lot! But considering that Pittsburgh has so many amazingly rated restaurants, I will be going to other newer places. If I get a chance though...I'm coming back.

uMeCWFQIxLTeMW1o9IPGsw.text: Second time here. Delicious food. Would eat here constantly if I could. Hot, timely, a little loud in the restaurant but over all I love eating here!

JllfF6qg2WCesLoeUok1_A.text: Had the pork soup dumplings , vegetable dumplings pork back rice and broccoli.  Definitely worth the visit for the dumplings as many others have noted. Quick and pleasant service.

ucDWwTWE2d6a4Pp_XwYTsQ.text: Soup dumplings in Pittsburgh.   I'm still trying to get my head around it.  They are still in soft-opening phase, we went for their second day of lunch service.  Much more organized than most places at this stage - we had good service although the place filled quickly.  Soup dumplings were very good, temperature and texture just right.  Hand-pulled noodle soup with wontons was excellent - the noodles stand up against some we had recently in Hong Kong.  Green onion pancake was great - chewy and with the perfect inside texture and salty oniony goodness.  Hot tea was kept filled and hot throughout our visit - something I've wished for in Pittsburgh forever.    Overall, super.  Can't wait to go back.

h5TN8j76zxdPtr1L-vYomw.text: Oh man, I ask myself "is this queasy feeling in my stomach going to last all night?" Terrible idea to come here, I should have waited the three minutes for a table at Ramen Bar. I walk in to Everyday Noodles and first my nose is telling me it wants me to turn back out the door. I know your nose is supposed to adjust to smells pretty fast so I decided to push past the signal my nostrils were sending to my brain. I settled on sesame noodles with chicken, my boyfriend was extremely daring and tried the braised beef noodle soup. There were many times we shared a romantic moment staring into each others' eyes, trying not to regurgitate the food back into our bowls, all while enjoying the rhythmic sounds of noodles being banged against the steel countertops.

n_P-lyV19Q7u9hKR0PdVqQ.text: This place is pretty much in our bucket list whenever we visit Pittsburgh. Love the dry Dan su noodle, the consistency is like Italian al dente pasta. Their soup dumpling skin is much thinner than anything I tried in nyc and this is exactly the style that we like.

6Z_4A5Xv77YXcAmHgjll7Q.text: The beef noodle soup is very good: the noodle is properly hand made to high quality, which gives an enduring texture; soup and beef are very tasty and decent.   The Szechuan style dumplings and noodles are not authentic, tasting ok; the noodles tasting more like the Shanghainese cold noodle.   The pork soup dumplings have very good skins, but I would say that the meat needs to be more firm and less greasy. Although in general, I am happy to see such quality in a city like Pittsburgh.  I guess the restaurant is Taiwanese, so anything close to the Taiwanese cuisine are a lot better than those that are not that close.

ZCoqPwknNnDZMpo4f206tg.text: Had the opportunity to revisit this establishment for Dim Sum with friends.  Once again, great tasting food; however, limited options for Dim Sum, and furthermore, additional limitations for the vegetarians out there.  The dumplings continue to be fantastic.  Also, the boba tea is very unique: being able to add toppings such as red beans, mango or coconut, among a few other choices-different to say the least.  Still wish portion sizes were larger for the price.  I'll probably be back, but I'm not ready to write home about this place, yet.

eyyO3ahDjII5Qe-Q7bJxag.text: Get here before dinner gets hopping as the place fills up fast. If not sure, call to see about the wait time.

DP_p-MZfhBp2-vyoiCrtKA.text: Very authentic restaurant.  The fact that they make fresh noodles is great, but adding grilled chicken is unavailable. Soups are good.

PjhNfozP5UOLexKRw77uLg.text: Place wasn't to bad ... Ordered the beef noodles soup.. It was made to go and was pretty good... Wish there was more tender beef then chewy unedible  fatty meat... But the beef that i did have was good ... Addin the hot sauce made it alot better as well ... Staff was nice and friendly ...

8Zb813GdwR3TxkKbPrz2zA.text: Eaten here a few times. Love to watch them making the noodles. Everything is delicious. The soup dumplings are superb. On a chilly day the soup just warms you. Also think their bubble tea is the best. I have tried almost everything on the menu and enjoy it all.

__ekoepXByEpI_LtzG_c1Q.text: I, I just died in your arms tonight ! Every day noodles has me singing 80's love song praises. Squirrel Hill is not my neighborhood so I had to trust the tastes of my friends and I'm glad I did. This joint rocked my world. I was in a group of 11 people so that meant some awesome non committal family style sharing was going on. I personally ordered beef stew/ soup and a pork belly slider and a Thai bubble tea. First off the slider is huge it's a slugger! Slider to me would be those lil tiny hamburgers from that glistening castle in the sky known as White Castle. It comes on a steamed bun amazing. The meat was perfect not greasy and the ground up peanuts gave it a sweet appeal. I also tried the soup dumplings. What magical sacks of flavor are these ????? Give the man or woman who figured out you could steam cook a dumpling with liquid inside a high five. The spicy eggplant tasted savory just like meat, making me reconsider my eating ways til I remembered how good fried chicken is. I tried the fried tofu just meh, baby Bok Choy meh and the cucumber pickle was raw .... My beef soup was ok and I brought it home to my Taiwanese partner who declared it ok to good, but this is a man who eats this stuff in Taipei every year. My son enjoyed his plain wide noodles and all was right with the world.

z6hpS0t6r7BnPTJZ2s3fmw.text: Always delicious. As a Chinese person, and just moving to Pittsburgh, this place is a gem.  Well worth the 25min drive on a weekday

kqCOW6mtiuGxWyk3WzVuUg.text: Came here on a Saturday afternoon for lunch, but it was so busy (and we were hungry!) that we decided to go back another day. Popular place! We had Dan Dan noodles, some dumpling with soup inside (can't remember its name) and rolled onion pancake with sliced beef. It was all delicious and definitely recommend this place!

wbQqOk_xmfYXa1QSvWShtw.text: I love the bubble teas here! They have five flavors and you get to choose two toppings besides bubble. My favorite combination is milk coffee with bubble and caramel pudding! Although I do hope they can provide different sizes like other bubble tea places do. They only have one size and it's really big!  .My personal favorite food here is the beef roll, and I will recommend you to try it! The pork soup dumplings are good, not "wow" good but at least tasty enough for me to go back.  Small dining area so go there early to avoid long wait!

7jmg_iHTEgDTBT6olP8zNA.text: Love this place. Handmade fresh noodles and dumplings that I never expected to find in pittsburgh. My preference is for the "dry" noodles, meaning noodles that are not in a soup or broth. I like the dry dan tsu noodles and the minced pork noodles. Soup dumplings are a must but should ideally be eaten at the restaurant. The pork belly slider is good but humongous, not really an appetizer. Could literally eat here every day.

0GJ3HsU0IeGzg3lFrvMHtg.text: does anybody know which soup dumplings are the best? i used to order the good ones, but lately they changed recipes and the new ones suuuucccck, too salty, super small, she said they ones for takeout are different than the ones for in dining room, weird wtf!

PZF2vFE6myxSnRypRmQCpg.text: Fast and courteous service. I was the only single in the restaurant and didn't like being seated separate from the rest, a bit lonely with only the soy sauce containers, napkins and computer to keep me company. Ordered the braised beef and tendon noodle soup and pickled cucumber appetizer. Shouldn't call these pickles as there was no vinegar, more of a veggie in brine plate. A little sweet and sour would have gone nice with what I knew would a salty soup. Beef was tender, and noodles perfectly chewy. Was a giant bowl with a lot of meat. Got two pieces of broccoli and one small slice of daikon, would have preferred a bit more veggies and less meat. Also wish the broth was more flavorful. Overall, a good experience for a fast in and out experience. Wouldn't bring anyone to impress them with my foodie skills, but satisfying when it's raining and you're hungry and you need a hot meal 10 minutes ago. By the way, don't order the beef and tendon unless you're adventurous, ok with eating fatty food, or grew up with this tradition dish. Most western tastes don't like the dish I find.

SWVWrudKn59ucuoPaFv8IQ.text: Love this place!  The soup dumplings are great here. I don't know any where else in pittsburgh that has them this good. Also love the vegetables in oyster sauce. The noodle bowls are really good. I haven't tried them all yet, but have been very happy with every one I've had so far

c2OvQa1vGXKB9QeWPvHCIA.text: Upon several recommendations I gave this place a try, and it is (almost) as good as everyone says it is. I ordered soup and a fried tofu appetizer, and was very impressed with the soup, but not so much with the app. A bit bland. But overall I was pleased and definitely would return. Also, watching the noodles being made added to the experience, and is something I haven't seen elsewhere.

ZsrBQnGS99pI0hMwjWz6kg.text: Outstanding noodles, dumplings, and Taiwanese. This is outstanding not just in Pittsburgh but generally. Great restaurant.

6Y-CyP0lNPsOjldZIJbKXA.text: Everyday Noodles is my favorite place to eat in Squirrel Hill. Service has been great and the food is amazingly good! The soup dumplings and pot stickers are my favorite. I do wish they served alcohol but its BYOB if you'd like some wine with your meal. Highly recommend!

dT90xaEDJAnVgNHHWGkZOQ.text: A hearty 5 stars on many fronts though not every front.  I'm trying not to give these 5-ers out so readily especially since I've been here only once but you can't ignore the quality of the noodles, buns, and "pi" (pea) or wonton skin.  I haven't had any of the broths here yet but every bowl I've seen ordered is returned pretty clean.  I believe Mr. Chang the owner also owns China Palace and Tamari.  If there is such a thing as a noodle snob in Pgh, you should pay this place a visit as it compares closest for me to the la mein of Vancouver, BC or Richmond, BC.  I will return, repeatedly.

fGyqmAzqbTXoKxvpECtoVQ.text: Overpriced and mediocre soup dumplings and noodles. Hyped place and disappointing food, nothing special. Not even really worth my time to write too much more about it. Doesn't even compare to the real deal you can get for a fraction of the price in NYC's chinatown. Skip, unless you are a hipster with no taste or just desperate for something that kinda resembles soup dumplings for lack of anything better in the area ;)

VGsPSliO3rHqkXqbKvLjlQ.text: Good soup dumpling ,good beef noodle, friendly waitress, but the red oil dumplings taste sweet!? And the Dan Dan noodle is a huge disappointment too.  Clear trans parent glass gives the spatial and cleanliness feeling, but if you look closely, the finger nails of the guys in the kitchen are black!  Debating between 2 and 3 stars .... Decide to give it a 3 because of the service ...

SgEJ2GY5Z6Jvsk5oDgijdw.text: Went for dim sum and had a good experience. The staff are very polite and accommodating, the atmosphere is pleasant, and the food was tasty. No complaints!

Yk3upjPqnmweLixpsTKq3w.text: I visited Everyday Noodles for the first time a few days ago and was quite impressed. First of all, the interior is very inviting, with a clear view of the kitchen, tasteful decor, and a cozy seating area. More importantly, the generously-portioned food is fresh, inventive, and of high qualty, especially considering the very low prices. I was especially fond of the pork belly slider. Everyday Noodles figures to become my go-to for Chinese in Squirrel Hill.

frBVoMo9m5ineAi1j2MUWA.text: I absolutely like how they make the noodles right in front of you as well as the layout of the restaurant. It's a bit small and crowded but I really like places like that.  The food is great and the portion size was just right. Definitely a place to check out if you are around there.

5YOzcOhmvqnyhIsXB7qoGQ.text: I've been here three times since its opening.  Let me start by saying that their wontons, potstickers, and dumplings are all excellent. Great consistency in the dough, good flavor in the filling. Their soup dumplings, especially, are heavenly.  And if this were all that they served, I'd be giving a four-star review right now.  However, their soups have let me down -- the noodles are certainly adequate (though I would like a bit more chewiness), but the broth in both soups I've been able to sample isn't very flavorful. And my dining companion noted that the braised beef was actually tough in her soup.  I will be returning, but I will likely be staying away from the soups.

Y4TcWmb20CFpwBIVd-Kj8Q.text: Price is right, food comes out quickly, perfect for a quick bite--not a place to go for a great meal.  I was disappointed that they did not have many warm chicken or shrimp meals!!  So, I ordered the Szechuan noodles* because I love spicy--they were mildly spicy and broth was really tasty.  Hubby had a beef and rice dish.  He was disappointed because the rice was dry (I gave him some of my sauce).   We also ordered a side of broccoli with pork sauce, tasty but not remarkable.  *Noodles were velvety--that was the best part of the meal.

B55drWWPRS0XRpZHnCopJA.text: Second time eating here and it was as great as the first. I tried the beef tendon with my soup and I highly recommend it. Service was also great both times and I again took home food for later because the bowls of soup are massive..

3hHDfhOzw_px65hnL4XJSw.text: It has a nice atmosphere and the staff are very nice. I found the noodle soup just so-so - decent flavor but the noodles were more like spaghetti, even if they are fresh. Not chewy enough. On that count the ramen place across the street is better. But I look forward to trying to soupy dumplings here, and some other dishes. I'd go back.

bn9fbi37VQfWSO3bavN4Jw.text: I love Everyday Noodles. They make their noodles from scratch, on the spot, and the broth that comes along is delicious. The beef tendon noodle soup is filling and fresh. Their milk teas are heavenly. Easily the best milk teas I've had so far. If you get a chance, go. It's worth the trip.

dqH8nk63x1PRmCGOxAWZkQ.text: The noodle was ok, not the best noodles I had, but the xiao long bao was pretty tasty..

W_5DkVq23KJpZddW9Ov07A.text: Delicious! Great little place in squirrel hill. Food was great. Soup dumplings=delicious. It's really cool because you can see the chefs make the noodles and dumplings through a glass window-- very interesting process! Would definitely recommend the place.

dtlME9siasq6GlmAp0qouQ.text: We tried out everyday noodles last night and loved it.   Word has gotten out quickly about this place, and even though it has been open only a few weeks, we had to wait 15 minutes or so.  And, boy was it worth it.  Our table was facing the kitchen and we were amazed and entertained by the guy behind the window making the noodles.  Every batch is made separately and by hand.  The way he flicks the noodles around which result in flat ones or thin round ones was very impressive.  More importantly the soupy dumplings, Rolled onion pancakes with beef, and the dan dan noodles were my three favorites.  We had both the pork and pork/carb soupy dumplings.  We couldn't agree which were better - you should have them both!

CdnLIeQMCD2NGgefmZoweA.text: Friend suggested we try everyday noodles and after looking at the menu, was quite intrigued by items such as: oxtail soup, and chicken/beef consomme. Didn't get a chance to try anything too adventurous my first time here, but will in the future. Had wood ears and tofu skins for appetizer, was delicious. Then we shared the vegetable dumplings, which were great with the homemade soy sauce and piping hot when delivered in the steaming basket. Then the soups came. My friend had gotten the dan dan noodles, which were spicy in a great way along with a sesame/oil sauce that he wanted to spoon into his mouth after he finished. I got the Wonton noodle soup which came with freshly wrapped pork/veggie wontons, and the housemade noodles (which were hand spun right in front of us as we got to sit in front of the chef window) that came with a spicy oil sauce. Wonderful. Wait staff was great, and even kindly entertained some questions others would have had trouble with.   All in all, great little place in squirrel hill, and right across from Tutti Frutti for dessert.

fy8THI5lJTND2PcWD3R_7A.text: I like it.  I am a fan of soups and dumplings.  I went back two times.  I tried their braised beef soup, soup dumplings, their braised pork with rice dish, and their tapioca milk tea.  The braised beef soup was good.  It was a generous portion.  Thick pieces of meat, lots of noodles, and a nice broth.  The broth was light.  It isn't as hearty as Pho.  I don't think I can eat it everyday like I can Pho.  The meat was soft and tasted good.  There are tons of noodles which I didn't finish.  I know everyone makes a big deal about how the noodles are fresh and made everyday.  Eh -- I don't think that's really important.  It is pretty annoying when they are making it and slamming the dough on the table every few minutes.  Their dumplings were good.  I tried several different kinds.  They were a little small but I found them to be tasty.  Their braised pork with rice was really good.  It had a side of boiled egg and some pickled vegetable.  There was a little too much fat on the pork but I found it delicious.  I tried their black tea flavored tapioca milk tea with grass jelly and coconut jelly.  I am pretty disappointed at the taste.  I didn't think it was very good and tasted nothing like tapioca milk tea.    I came here during a Wed and Satruday.  Saturday was super busy.  I don't think I saw my waitress again after the initial ordering.  The Wednesday was slower.  But I had an issue with my drink.  The support staff to the waitress doesn't seem to know what they're doing.  But the waitress was extremely nice.  Overall, I did like the food and I do see myself coming back.

3OIMJD3K1aD1M26fgvRLdQ.text: Food is good, although it is slightly overpriced. The waiters/waitresses are nice, too. It can get noisy because the chef slams the dough on the kitchen counter a lot, but I suppose that's one of the selling points - you can actually see the chef make noodles right in front of you. Good for casual dinner. Can get crowded at times.

3YuEUMHiiskGazXzot2EyA.text: I have been to this location 5 times ,always busy,most of time have to wait 10 to 20 mins to be seated ,but it's worth,I've try different things every time ,with family or friends,very enjoy,ambience,food,especially service,very friendly manager ADY,owner STEVE come to our table every time ,surprise to see negative reviews about this place,overpriced,tasteless,blah ......,I understand the sweat and tears go into making a business ,I've never write a review,just feel like to say something about this place to let people know

X8-GMS1vgojZi_eNMQ1AKA.text: A bit pricey considering what is served, but I won't go ahead and complain about the price since the food taste good! The noodles were made fresh in store, and taste authentic. None of us were big fan of their soup dumplings though. My only complaint is the waiting time. 5 pm Sunday night, Pitt spring break, and there was already a line waiting for a table! Ok, I get it. This is Pittsburgh, where people get excited when a new Asian restaurant opens. However, the food simply doesn't worth any waiting longer than 10 minutes! Actually, I was very fortunate to get there by 4.30, and didn't wait that long for a table. But seeing all those people waiting, I felt the pressure to finish quick and let those poor people have their meals. I would prefer to spend my cozy Sunday night in a less popular place.

pbJYK9I9_F3ft_nEQYNU4g.text: I found about this restaurant from the internet a couple of days ago and decided to give it a shot for all the reviews were good. Not so surprisingly, all my family found the dishes we ordered very tasty and well served. The staff met our needs and were kind. We especially liked the oxtail noodle soup and would love to go again!

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Wonton noodle soup was delicious!

pR4gCZU0QV8p3kunUHlHuw.text: So many people have already posted about the soup dumplings and it's True. They are delicious. We have visited twice and both time have ordered, and eaten, enough food for 4 people.  We have tried: Szechuan style wontons- these came with spicy glass noodles as well as the wontons. Very nice with lots of heat  Pork vegetable and shrimp pot stickers- I adore that these are steamed and then friend like a pancake and you have to break the pot stickers out. They were yummy and so uniquely presented! Pan fried green onion pancake- Chris wasn't a huge fan. It wasn't something he would order again. Don't get me wrong it wasn't bad, but when everything else is so good you just can't waste stomach room on less than stellar items Pork soup dumplings- these have a darker soup broth which gives them a completely different flavor than the pork and crab soup dumplings. They are filled with warm soup and really good Pork and shrimp shu mai- these are one of my favorites. Tons of flavor, try them with some red oil. Pork and crab meat soup dumplings- these are hands down one of the top 10 best things I've ever eaten! The broth in these is light and loaded with flavor. I would eat an entire bowl of just the broth! And then you get the awesome meaty filling. Good lord they are divine! We still haven't made it back for a Sunday to try the shrimp with loofah soup dumplings, hopefully soon!

DDjURzsaXR8OxVwB7aocaQ.text: All I can say is GREAT FOOD!! Pork soup dumplings are the best thing ever...the pork belly slider tasted fantastic and the Thai tea is amazing. We have been 4 times is 2 weeks, truly my new favorite

HHXJ9X3BMBSc4KQipRdp-Q.text: It was great restaurant. The lamb noodle soup is supper. The soup dumpling is make in the glass kitchen.

fVOLQwm4MtfNI9o6zSf_aA.text: Overall good experience. The soup dumplings and Gyoza are very good, but soup noodles  and cucumber  are big disappointments.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. You mush have a try!

7QarlpO4K8rqc2UPygLFOA.text: The pork soup dumplings were so good!!! The wonton soup was a bit bland, but still good - next time I would just get it with the noodles. Everyone in our party loved it. Will definitely go back!

iI8tcvCN88pv6CL61V6PQQ.text: Soup dumplings are soooo good. U should definitely try their bubble tea!!! Pork belly is kind of sweet to me. Noodles are good choice for coming to the store.

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. pork
Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. soup

GFGtWqBF3aUQGrd_A4cg7Q.text: I tried Everyday Noodles on a visit to Pittsburgh, having graduated from CMU 8 years ago. Nothing this authentic existed in the city back then, and I shudder to think  how much weight I would have gained if it had opened prior to 2006.   The soup dumplings were small, but delicious; the skins were nice and thin. The braised beef was tender and the noodle soup broth flavorful. Amazing.   I wish I lived closer; I'd come all the time if I weren't 4 hours away.

1O4L-k0w7wjQY7Qn-Pg7FA.text: Came here for the first time today. I heard that this place was pretty authentic, and it's True! If you've ever been to din tai feng in Taiwan, or any other similar type restaurant it's just like that. The best part, it's in Pittsburgh!  Everything ordered was pretty good- dan dan noodles, drunken chicken, watercress, and xiao long bao. If you go for sure order the xiao long bao and a noodle dish. The noodles are made fresh in the window!

t16JBbSIOtPWgThyoVIjmQ.text: This restaurant has very authentic Taiwanese food and reminds me of my grandma's cooking. I am never disappointed by the quality of the hand-made noodles and sauces that come along with all of the variation. One thing I have noticed over the numerous times I've been there is that their soup dumplings have become smaller and smaller in size. The flavor of the soup dumplings is very similar to my favorite soup dumpling restaurant in Asia so I highly recommend this place!

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Dan shu noodles and pork soup dumplings. That&#39;s home in two dishes.

lnGUh0AVDOx1ozmXhyWd_A.text: We decided to try this place out due to the high ratings and boy are we glad that we did!   We went in on a Saturday night around 8 o'clock and were greeted by a friendly hostess, told the wait was about twenty minutes, not bad at all for a Sat night.  We ordered the Dan Dan noodles, pork soup dumplings, onion pancake, and finished it wish some doughy yolky dessert  all was top notch!  Service was FAST and very friendly.  Will be back again!

photos.caption: Photo of Everyday Noodles - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Dessert!  This hot,doughy, yolky, sweetness was a nice treat!

eqXFomYklgJf7tMvQclTHA.text: Everday Noodles is a godsend. The food is fantastic and unlike anything I've ever had before. I had the sesame cold noodles for my entree, which were refreshing on a summer day and were delicious.
